For example, NITA offers trainings to both their staff and others in government ministries, institutions, and agencies (1) (2) & (3). Whereas Uganda Bureau of Statistics in statistical aspects including data collection, analysis and dissemination (3) (4) (5). The Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development that is responsible for financing these trainings and the two institutions (6). It is important to note that trainings in Uganda are offered in workshops. They target mostly civil servants at national level and rarely targets local government civil servants. There is also evidence of Non-governmental Organisations offering trainings on data aspects. For example, since 2009, Development Initiatives in Uganda has been training stakeholders including public servants on data (7). In addition, African Freedom of Information Centre (AFIC) offered training to public officials and CSOs on open contracting (8).

There are also the UAE Hackathons, launched in 2018 and organized yearly in all UAE Emirates (2). Hackathons are organized in Universities and provides training, workshop and seminars for participants to reinforce their knowledge with data in addition to the support of couches and data experts.

Uzbekistan,UZB,Capabilities,CAPABILITIES,C.CAPABILITIES.TRAIN,Capability (C): Civil service,Primary,C.CAPABILITIES.TRAIN,To what extent is the government providing training to develop civil servants' data literacy and data skills?,1,response,"Training courses at the Institute for Staff Advanced Training and Statistical Research [1] can be organized in the form of retraining or advanced training courses, depending on the category of students. The retraining course is designed for employees working in the state statistics system, but whose previous education (higher or secondary special) is not in statistics and economics. In this course, students complete a 576-hour program and at the end of the course defend their dissertation, with successful graduates being awarded a standard diploma. The refresher course is designed for all categories of employees working in government statistics and lasts at least 36 hours. Individuals who are newly hired into the system, but do not have the relevant experience and qualifications, are required to take advanced training courses within one month from the date of employment. In addition, employees transferring to higher organizations within the system must improve their skills in the relevant training courses within the next three months from the date of transfer to the new position. In general, according to the current procedure, every employee working in the system should be covered by advanced training courses at least once every two years. Students who have completed advanced training courses will be issued a certificate in the prescribed form.

Additionally, from March 1 to March 31, 2021, the State Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Statistics[2] organized training sessions on preliminary preparation for conducting multi-indicator cluster surveys. The training was attended by selected supervisors and interviewers from the Republic of Karakalpakstan, the city of Tashkent, and other regions.

The training took place in two stages. At the first stage, the participants were given the concepts of multi-indicator cluster surveys, the structure of the questionnaires, the content and essence of the questions. In the questionnaires, knowledge, and skills were given on the correct, understandable transmission of questions to respondents, and the conduct of surveys.

At the second stage, trial surveys were carried out in the selected mahallas of the Yunusabad district of the capital, Zangiotinsky, and Yangiyul districts of the Tashkent region. Plates were used in trial surveys.

For information: starting from April 5 of this year, the survey process will be collected electronically on tablets in 14,520 households located in 726 selected mahallas in the Republic of Uzbekistan, through personal conversations with respondents in the field.

As a result of the training, about 100 supervisors and interviewers selected from the Republic of Karakalpakstan, the city of Tashkent, and regions were awarded special certificates from the State Statistics Committee and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

Angola,AGO,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Angola peculiarly practices a dual legal system for data protection. While the Personal Data Protection Law makes copious procedural provisions for observance of data protection principles and enforcement of rights, a Presidential Decree effectively creates the office of Data Protection Authority to ensure compliance with the data protection law.

The Angolan data protection law generally and specifically regulates the processing of personal data by both the public and private bodies. It regulates both manual and electronic processing of personal data by controllers and processors based in the country and processing activities by any means in the country irrespective of controllers' location. The law effectively covers only processing done in the country.

Armenia,ARM,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Armenia adopted the Law on Protection of Personal Data on May 18th, 2015 (1). It was followed by the Prime Minister's decree approving the list of measures to ensure the implementation of the law (2).
The Agency for Protection of Personal Data of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia is the authorized state body for the protection of personal data. The Agency ensures:
1. maintenance of the registry for those processing personal data;
2. protection of the rights of subjects of relations connected with the protection of personal data;
3. within the scope of its competence, lawful processing of personal data.
The Agency has published guides on children's personal data, video surveillance, personal data related to labor relations, the protection of personal data on social media, among others.
Sources
(1): RA Law on Protection of Personal Data, 18 May 2015
(2): RA Prime Minister's Decree N573A

Australia,AUS,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"While a framework exists, recent developments in the complexity of data ecosystems means that The Australian legal, regulatory, and policy landscape offers a mechanism for data protection and a mechanism for the responsible stewardship of personal data but only partially.1

The Privacy Act (1988) applies to Government Agencies and Private Organisations with an annual turnover greater than AUD $3000,000. Political Parties and Small businesses are excluded from the Act but may be required to comply with jurisdictional or Telecommunication, Healthcare, or National Security legislation.2 The Privacy Act centers around 12 Privacy Principles and entities are required to self-determine ""reasonable"" levels of self-governed compliance based on their organisational structure.3

The Privacy Act applies to the Commonwealth of Australia, it's important to note the States and Territories of Australia have separate Data and Privacy laws that organisations operating within those jurisdictions must adhere to in addition to Commonwealth Law.

A review of the Australian Privacy Act began in October of 2020 with an issue paper,4 outlining the scope of the consultation. Notably, this includes consideration of a 2014 Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) report that found a statutory privacy tort to be included to provide an avenue for Australian citizens to pursue legal recourse for privacy breaches.5
Sources:
1 Interview with Suneel Jethani, Engagement Manager - Open Data Initiative, Victorian state government, July 2021.
2 Australian Privacy Act, No. 119, 1988, https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2014C00076

4 Australian Government Attorny-General's Deperatment, October 2020, Privacy Act Issue Paper, https://www.ag.gov.au/system/files/2020-10/privacy-act-review--issues-paper-october-2020.pdf

Azerbaijan,AZE,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Personal Data Law of Azerbaijan Republic (11 May 2010, 998-IIIQ), section 7.1.1 indicates that everyone has a right to get information on the availability of personal information about him(her)self from the owner or operator of the information system that collects personal data. Section 8.1. indicates that, the collection and processing of personal data about any person are allowed only with written consent, or in the form of an electronic document with the electronic signature of a person. The only exception is for cases of compulsory collection and processing of personal data in the manner prescribed by the legislation of the Azerbaijan Republic.

Section 7.1. of the Law (- Receiving information about their personal data; - Receiving information about the intention of the personal data collection; - Requesting to correct or delete personal data).

Article 12 (a person can request information about his/her personal data. Data collectors should provide complete information, free of charge, within 7 days (in case of urgent need, it can be extended 7 days).

According to the Law, those that collect personal data should create a security system that prevents unintentional use of personal data. In case of a personal data breach, the personal data collector should compensate the data owner for damage, and its amount is determined by the court.
The Law does not cover explicitly the types of data and actions depending on the types of data.
General conclusion:

Personal Data Law of Azerbaijan Republic (11 May 2010, 998-IIIQ) provides a comprehensive framework to protect and regulate personal data collection, usage, and removal.  The adoption of the Law is related to the approval of the Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data (ETS No.108) by the Azerbaijan Republic.
Personal data information systems must be registered with the Ministry of Transport, Communications, and High Technologies. All personal data collectors are listed on the website of the Registry (5).

Bahrain,BHR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Bahrain enacted Law No. 30 of 2018 with respect to Personal Data Protection (""PDPL"") on July 12, 2018. The personal data protection law is the main data protection regulation in Bahrain, it came into force on August 1st 2019, and supersedes any law with contradictory provisions (1).
The Ministry of Justice, Islamic Affairs and Waqf was designated, by Royal Decree No. (78) of 2019, to assume the duties of the Personal Data Protection Authority (2).
The personal data protection authority website show a set of executive decisions published for consultation (3), 8 in total related to :
1- The duties of the Data Protection Guardian
2- The Data Subject Rights
3- The conditions to be met in the technical and organizational measures that guarantee protection of data
4- Public Directories
5- The Rules and Procedures of Data Processing
6- The Rules and Procedures Governing Submission of Complaints Relating to Personal Data Protection
7- Sensitive Data Processing Procedures
8- States, Countries and Territories with Adequate Legislative and Regulatory Protection for Personal Data
## References
1- http://www.pdp.gov.bh/en/regulations.html
2- http://www.pdp.gov.bh/en/royal-decree.html

Bangladesh,BGD,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Section 7(h, i, r) of Right to Information Act, 2009 provides protection from disseminating personal data against RTI request.

However, Section 26(1) of Digital Security Act 2018 states provides protection of personal data from a criminal point of view. Quote from the law: ""If any person collects, sells, possesses, provides or uses identity information of any other person without lawful authority, then such act of the person shall be an offence.""

Benin,BEN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Benin's digital code (Loi n°2017-20 du 20 avril 2018 portant code du numérique en République du Bénin) (1) is devoted to personal data. This book addresses all aspects of the issue of personal data. It was set up following a large series of consultations that allowed for the consideration of practices, laws, treaties, conventions and regulations that address the issue at the level of ECOWAS, the African Union, the European Union and the United Nations.

Bolivia,BOL,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Bolivia there is no comprehensive regulation on personal data. However, there are regulations that mention personal data issues but from different approaches.

The Political Constitution of the Plurinational State of Bolivia (1) has a basic article, Article 21.2, which states that Bolivians have the right to privacy, intimacy, honor, their own image and dignity. The 130 called Privacy Protection Action.

On the other hand, other laws and codes have mentions about privacy; Among them it is worth highlighting article 54 of the General Law of Telecommunications and Information and Communication Technologies (2), on the rights of users to privacy, and deciding on the data included in the telephone number directories that are available to the public.

Likewise, the amendment to Article 79 of the Electoral Body Law (3) that allows the Civic Registry Service (SERECI) to interoperate with the General Identification Service (SEGIP) contains provisions on the security of personal data and grants them to the and Bolivians to be able to consult the stored personal data in order to authenticate and validate the information.

Additionally, we have Article 56 of the Regulation for the Development of Information and Communication Technologies (4), which when referring to the digital certificate provides the person with a control framework over their data based on the idea of ​​consent.
Finally, the recent Law on digital citizenship (5) in its Article 12 provides for the processing of personal data must be limited to the purpose established by law.

Botswana,BWA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Justification: Botswana does not have an AI national policy strategy yet neither does the proposed Data Protection Act address any code of standards for public sector use of AI technology and algorithmic decision-making systems.

Brazil,BRA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Brazil offers a comprehensive framework for protecting personal data. Since 2010 the legal framework for the protection of personal data has been developed in the country (1). The chronology is as follows: in 2013 a bill was proposed on the processing and use of personal data in the Federal Senate; in 2015 the project proposal was approved; in 2017, other projects began to be processed in the Chamber and Senate; the General Personal Data Protection Law was enacted in August 2018; in 2019, the creation of the National Data Protection Authority was approved; the general protection law entered into force in August 2020 (2).

Law no. 13.709, of August 14, 2018, General Law for the Protection of Personal Data provides citizens with control over the treatment of their data, through principles and rules that must be observed by private and public organizations.

The main foundations (3) of the law respect for, informative self-determination, freedom of expression, information, communication, and opinion; inviolability of intimacy, honor, and image; economic and technological development and innovation; free enterprise, free competition, and consumer protection; human rights, the free development of personality, dignity and the exercise of citizenship by natural persons.

The law provides under which circumstances the processing of data can be carried out, distinguishes personal data from sensitive data, determines the rights of the data subject regarding the processing, collection, and control; establishes the principles of data processing by the government; creates two people to control, operate and respond to data processing, the person in charge and the controller (3).

The general law was modified to create compliance guidelines and the oversight body. Law no. 13,853, of July 8, 2019 (4) established measures to ensure compliance with data protection rules, created the National Data Protection Authority, a body linked to the Presidency of the Republic, and the National Council for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy.

The authority is responsible for drafting the guidelines for the National Policy for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy; monitor and apply sanctions in case of non-compliance with the law or irregularities. The authority must promote knowledge of the norms for the population, safety and security policies, and cooperate with authorities in other countries.

The National Council for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy acts as a consultation body for the national authority, proposing guidelines, providing subsidies for the creation of national policy, preparation of studies, debates, and public hearings (4). The Council is composed of members of civil society and public authorities, who were recently selected through a public notice (5).
Source:

(1) LUGATI, L.N.; ALMEIDA, J.E. de. The evolution of data protection legislation: the need to reassess the role of consent as a guarantor of informative self-determination. Journal of Law, [S. l.], v. 12, no. 02, p. 01-33, 2020. DOI: 10.32361/2020120210597. Available at: https://periodicos.ufv.br/revistadir/article/view/10597. Accessed on: July 17, 2021.
(2) Timeline of Personal Data Protection and the General Personal Data Protection Law in Brazil. Available at: https://www.serpro.gov.br/lgpd/menu/arquivos/linha-do-tempo/view
(3) General Guide to the General Personal Data Protection Law. Available at: https://www.gov.br/cidadania/pt-br/acesso-a-informacao/lgpd

(4) LAW No. 13.853, OF JULY 8, 2019 amends Law No. 13.709, of August 14, 2018, to provide for the protection of personal data and to create the National Data Protection Authority, and makes other arrangements. Available at: http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2019-2022/2019/lei/13853.htm

(5) Composition of the National Council for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy. Available at: https://www.gov.br/anpd/pt-br/composicao-1/conselho-nacional-de-protecao-de-dados-pessoais-e-privacidade-cnpd/indicacoes-ao-cnpd",2.0,1.0,1.0,90.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,ILDA,South America,Latin America and the Caribbean,São Paulo,Sao Paulo,-23.55,-46.6333,BR,admin,Gobernanza

Bulgaria,BGR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Constitution of the Republic of Bulgaria – art. 32 and art. 34 – provide the legal basis for the inviolability of the privacy of citizens and of their freedom and confidentiality of correspondence and all other communications. (1) The Republic of Bulgaria is a member of the European Union (EU). The Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (GDPR) (2) has a direct effect and is directly applicable in Bulgaria's legal order. The Regulation's provisions that need to be specified are implemented and completed on the national level by the Personal data protection act. (3)

The EU personal data protection framework of which the GDPR is a part applies to all sectors. An exception to the GDPR, but as a part of the EU personal data protection framework is the sector of Law enforcement, which is covered by the Directive (EU) 2016/680 on the protection of natural persons regarding processing of personal data connected with criminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data which (4) is also implemented on the national level by the Personal data protection act.
(1) Constitution of the Republic of Bulgaria. 1991. National Assembly. https://www.parliament.bg/en/const

(2) Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (GDPR). 2016. EUR-Lex. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2016/679/oj
(3) Personal data protection act. 2002. Commission for Personal Data Protection. https://www.cpdp.bg/en/index.php?p=element&aid=1194

(4) Directive (EU) 2016/680 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Council Framework Decision 2008/977/JHA. 2016. EUR-Lex. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv%3AOJ.L_.2016.119.01.0089.01.ENG",2.0,1.0,1.0,100.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Access Info Europe,Eastern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Sofia,Sofia,42.7,23.33,BG,primary,Gobernanza

Burkina Faso,BFA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"A framework exists and has the force of law for the protection of personal data. This is law no. 001-2021/an on the protection of persons with regard to the processing of personal data(1). The data protection authority in Burkina Faso is the Commission de l'Informatique et des Libertés (CIL) (2), (3).

The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent. The data subject's right section mentions this. Indeed, according to Article 12 of the Law on the Protection of Persons with regard to the Processing of Personal Data, unless otherwise provided for by law, it is prohibited to collect or process, without the express consent of the data subject, personal data that reveal religious, philosophical, political, trade union or ethnic beliefs or activities, sex life, race, health and morality, genetic and biometric data, social measures, prosecution, criminal or administrative sanctions. Articles 17 and 20 of the law also mention this (1).

The framework provides data subjects with rights of access and rectification of data concerning them. The data subject's right section indicates this. According to Article 16 of the Act on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data, the controller shall proactively provide the person whose data are processed, at the latest at the time of collection from the person or from a third party and regardless of the means and media used, with information such as the existence of a right of access to the data concerning him or her, as well as a right to rectification and deletion of such data. This information obligation does not apply to the collection of personal data necessary for the detection of an offence concerning State security, defence and public safety. This exemption from the obligation to inform the data subject applies only to the collection of data (1). Basically, this indicator provides good information regarding the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data.

Cambodia,KHM,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"At present the only relevant law to personal data protection is the E-Commerce Law. Cambodia's Ministry of Interior announced on 26 January 2021 that its lawyers and data specialists had met to discuss an initial draft of a sub-decree consisting of six chapters and 16 articles on the management, use, privacy and security of data collected by the government that can potentially be used to identify individuals (see https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/ministry-interior-working-privacy-protections-data). There is no information on when the drafting process will be completed. Cambodia is also working on reviewing and updating its draft cybercrime law, which contains specific data protection clauses that address preservation of data during criminal investigations, search and seizure of computer data for use as evidence, and potential safeguards for suspects to prevent data privacy abuses. Suggested fines and/or terms of imprisonment have been outlined in the Draft Law for potential cybercrime offences, which include accessing a computer system without a legal right and engaging in data espionage, illegal interception of non-public computer transmissions, and data interference, among others. The draft cybercrime law, originally drafted in 2016, is still pending final approval. In mid-2019, the Cambodian government announced that it was reviewing the draft law to ensure its consistency with current laws and to better outline potential punishments for offenses of it. A third draft was allegedly completed in mid-2020, but none of the drafts have been shared with the public or consulted with civil society organisations or local or international experts. Human Rights Watch, which has obtained a copy of the latest draft, alleges that the law if adopted in its current version will infringe on privacy rights and free speech online and should be scrapped (see https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/11/13/cambodia-scrap-draft-cybercrime-law).",2.0,1.0,1.0,3.399999999999998,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,East-West Management Institute Inc. (EWMI),South-Eastern Asia,South and East Asia,Phnom Penh,Phnom Penh,11.5694,104.9211,KH,primary,Gobernanza

Cameroon,CMR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Currently, there is no general data protection law or privacy law in Cameroon. The preparation of a general data protection bill is ongoing, spearheaded by the services of the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. This ""Privacy Bill"" is expected to govern the collection, processing, transmitting, storage, and use of data. As a specific data protection law is still yet to be adopted, it is quite challenging for users to control the use of their data. Nevertheless, the issue of protecting data has become a regulatory and legislative concern in Cameroon.

Data protection is a right enshrined in the Constitution of the Republic of Cameroon, Law No. 96/6 of 18 January 1996 revising the Constitution of 02 June 1972, as amended and supplemented by Law No. 2008/001 of 14 April 2008, which provides for the right to protection against any privacy interference and for the right to the privacy of correspondence. Legal and privacy-oriented provisions on data protection are also found in various pieces of legislation and governing texts, as well as in landmark case law.
Sources :

Cameroon Law on Electronic Communications : http://www.art.cm/sites/default/files/documents/Loi_2010-013_communications_electroniques.pdf

Canada,CAN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada is responsible for protecting personal information, through enforcing two federal laws: the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA) for the private sector (1), and the Privacy Act for the public sector (2). In 2020, they launched a consultation on regulating artificial intelligence as it relates specifically to PIPEDA (3). A new bill (C-11) was introduced with the Consumer Privacy Protection Act at its core and, once enacted, it is set to replace parts of the PIPEDA, modernizing and extending rules governing the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information for commercial activity in Canada (4).

Chile,CHL,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Chile there is a legal framework that allows protection of personal data (Law 19628. ABOUT PROTECTION OF PRIVATE LIFE. MINISTRY GENERAL SECRETARIAT OF THE PRESIDENCY). However, this law is out of date for the current context. In this law, there are no references on algorithmic transparency and no clear responsibilities are established for the use of personal data by the private sector.

China,CHN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"China currently has no single law in effective providing an comprehensive framework regulating personal information protection yet though the ""Personal Information Protection Law"" (1) has been drafted for public consultation for two rounds during 2020-2021 and a third and final draft is expected to be reviewed in August 2021 and is expected to be passed within 2021.

In addition to the ""Personal Information Protection Law"", the framework on personal information protection has been dramatically developed in recent years especially during the period from 2016 to 2021. The ""CyberSecurity law""  effective in 2017 (2), ""Information Security Technology — Personal Information Security Specification""(3) effective in 2020 and  ""Civil Code"" (4) effective in 2021 as well as other fragmented sector-specific or issue-specific regulations, guidelines and specifications all together already make a robust and strong framework for personal information protection. The Cybersecurity Law sets out the legal principles and high-level requirements on protection of personal data collected and / or processed via the networks operators.  And the Article 111 of the Civil Code sets out the basic principle that natural person's personal data shall be protected by law; any organization and individuals must collect personal data after obtaining the personal data subject's consent and conduct the collection according to the law; they shall ensure the security of the personal data collected; illegal collection, using, processing and transmitting of others' personal data, illegal transaction of selling / purchasing personal data, and illegal provision / disclosure of personal data shall be prohibited.
Key elements of Personal Information Protection are discussed below:

- Choice and consent: The Civil Code Chapter 6 ""Privacy and Personal Information Protection"" layouts the general foundation and guidelines for personal information processing stating that first an individual must be well informed of the purposes and procedures of processing personal information and second an explicit consent must be obtained to legally process personal information . The Cybersecurity law (Article 41) and the draft of Personal Information Protection Law (Article 13) also provides similar statements. The Article 17 of the drafted Personal Information Protection Law also empowers the individual to access to service even without giving any consent to process personal information whenever it's possible.

Above frameworks also layouts exceptions for consent if allowed by relevant laws and regulations : for instance under the condition of a national security or public health emergency case, or  news report that is relevant to public interest.

- Access and correction: The Civil Code Article 1037 empowers people the right to access and copy own personal information and has the right to correct and ask to delete information. The draft of Personal Information Protection Law specifies the data subject's right to access and correct own information. The article 44-45 grants the data subject's the right to know what information is held by the data handler and has the right to access. The article 46-47 empowers the data subject to correct and even delete relevant personal information.
- Responsibilities on data holders:
[a] taking steps to ensure personal information is updated and accurate;

The Article 8 of the draft Personal Information Protection Law states a general principle for personal information processing that high data quality is required so data should be accurate and up-to-date to avoid any possible negative impact on personal rights.
[b] limiting access to personal data in accordance with its intended use;

The Article 14 of the draft Personal Information Protection Law requires that the data holder must re-obtain consent if the purpose of collecting and using personal information has been changed. Article 22 further requires that the data holder should be responsible for limiting the data access and use if the third party is contracted to process personal information.
[c] only transferring data to third-parties if there are assurances they will also respect data protection rights

Article 23-24 requires that if transferring data to third-parties is necessary then the transfer should be agreed with the data subject and the third parties should process data under the original agreed purpose. If it is necessary to change the purpose of use, then new consent must be obtained.
[d] destroying or anonymising data after it is no longer needed for its original intended use.
Article 47 of draft Personal Information Protection Law  requires that data holder should proactively delete personal information if it is no longer needed for its original intended use.
- Rights of redress:

The Article 68 and 69 of draft Personal Information Protection Law empowers individual to ask compensation if personal informoation processing leads to any negative impact on the individual. In the case of multiple individuals or a collective are affected,  then relevant agency or authority has the right to sue the data holder on behalf of the group of individuals.
The independent oversight however is only limited to the designated authority while there is no specific Articles encourage civic society orgnaization to provide independent oversight.
- Breach notification:

The Article 56 of draft Personal Information Protection Law requires that data holder should report the breach immediately to the individual and relevant agency and explain what information are breached and possible negative impact and consequences, why and how the information are breached, what has been done to minimize the negative impact and what actions are suggested to the impacted individuals.
The similar requirements were also covered by the Article 42 of Cybersecurity law, the section 10.2 of Personal Information Security Specification and Article 1038 of Civil Code.
- Location data:
The location-related data is covered in the definition of what is personal information. The Civil law defined personal information includes personal location history information.
- Algorithmic decision-making:

The Article 55 of draft Personal Information Protection Law  requires that data holders should conduct risk assessment  before employing any algorithmic decision making and keep assessment records for at least three years.

The Article 25 of draft Personal Information Protection Law requires the transparency and fairness of decision made by algorithmic system. It further empowers individuals to receive alternative decisions not based upon personal information,  seek explanation and refuse any decisions solely made by algorithmic system.

(1) 个人信息保护法草案(二审),Draft Personal Information Protection Law (Second Draft),https://www.sohu.com/a/463852112_120076174 (link to a version comparing the first draft with second draft for easy reference)
(2) 信息安全技术个人信息安全规范, ""Information Security Technology — Personal Information Security Specification"",https://www.tc260.org.cn/upload/2018-01-24/1516799764389090333.pdf
(3) 中华人民共和国网络安全法, Cybersecurity Law,http://www.cac.gov.cn/2016-11/07/c_1119867116.htm

Colombia,COL,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Colombia, there is a legal framework regarding personal data implemented through Law 1581 of 2012 (1). This Law dictates general provisions for data protection. The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent and provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves. But the Framework doesn't explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.

Also there are initiatives such as Sandbox, a preventive, supervised and temporary experimentation space for those interested in developing artificial intelligence (AI) (2). Sandbox is a preventive, supervised, and temporary experimentation space based on AI projects to create collaborative compliance solutions to personal data protection standards. (https://www.sic.gov.co/sandbox-microsite)

Costa Rica,CRI,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In 2011, the Legislative Assembly approved the Law for the Protection of the Person against the processing of their personal data, and its regulations. The latter was the subject of a reform in 2016 to specify the scope of the standard in aspects that initially raised doubts.

Now Law 8968 falls short, due to the changes that have been witnessed since its approval, and current law initiatives in the world refer to instruments such as the General Data Protection Regulation of the European Union.

In addition, in the country the discussion around the protection of personal data has gained relevance. The foregoing by the questioned Presidential Data Analysis Unit (UPAD), whose function was to use data intelligence for public policy, including through access to confidential information. The decree was repealed after the wave of criticism and the investigation is ongoing.
In 2021, (2) deputies of the ruling party presented the legislative initiative Comprehensive Reform of the Law for the Protection of the Person Against the Treatment of Personal Data.

Croatia,HRV,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) prescribes the same rules on personal data protection for all member states. (1) The GDPR is robust legislation, but with law enforcement difficulties, as stated in the Access Now's implementation progress report ""Three Years Under the EU GDPR."" (2)

The main obstacles are the differences in national procedures and the lack of standard sets of handling cases. The Act on the Implementation of the GDPR  states that the Croatian Personal Data Protection Agency (AZOP) protects the rights guaranteed by the GDPR. Therefore, the national legislation is more concerned about the work, powers, and obligations of the AZOP and defines some specific cases of processing of personal data. (2)

France,FRA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The protection of personal data in France is regulated by three frameworks: the law n° 2018-493 on the protection of personal data, June 20, 2018 (1) that brings the law n° 78-17 on Information Technology, Data Files and Civil Liberty, January 6, 1978 (2) into line with the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)(3). It means that two national laws and one European directive have full force in France. Notwithstanding, the French national framework can limit or extend the European directive. The application of national law and European regulation is controlled by the CNIL (National Commission on Informatics and Liberty), an independent French administrative regulatory body founded by the law of 6 January 1978, and its power and sanction extended by the law of June 20, 2018. The CNIL mission is to ensure that data privacy law is applied to the collection, storage, and use of personal data (4).

There is no specific protection of location-related data mentioned in the French laws. However, since May 2021, the label SecNumCloud is delivered to companies that host their data in France by the French National Security Agency of Information Systems (ANSSI)(5).

(3) The General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, 2016: https://gdpr-info.eu/
(4) CNIL: https://www.cnil.fr/fr/les-droits-pour-maitriser-vos-donnees-personnelles

Georgia,GEO,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Law of Georgia on Personal Data Protection was enacted in 2011 and the latest revision dates back to 2019 (1). The law asserts that data processing shall be admissible if there is a data subject's consent; Article 15 of the law guarantees the data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves. Article 4 lays out the main - principles for data processing. Chapter 6 and 7 of the law on data protection outline the main areas of activity of the Personal Data Protection Inspector and the measures applied by the Inspector for the enforcement of law;

State Inspector's Service is an independent state authority that, as a legal successor of the Office of the Personal Data Protection Inspector, operates in Georgia since May 2019(2). The national framework does not address algorithmic decision-making and location data, nor does it obligate data-controllers and data-processors to notify any appropriate authorities. The Law on Personal Data Protection applies to the entire territory of Georgia and to public agencies as well as natural or legal persons, as inferred from the definitions provided by the framework. Furthermore, Georgia has been moving towards implementing and enforcing the GDPR(3), but this process is at a very early stage for the time being.

Ghana,GHA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"""The Data Protection Act, 2012 (Act 843) provides the grounding for the protection of privacy of the individual and personal data by regulating the processing of personal information, to provide the process to obtain, hold, use or disclose personal information and for related matters"".

The Data Protection Commission (DPC) is an independent statutory body established under the Data Protection Act, 2012 (Act 843) to protect the privacy of the individual and personal data by regulating the processing of personal information.

The Data Protection Act, 2012 (Act 843) sets out the rules and principles governing the collection, use, disclosure and care of your personal data or information by a data controller or processor. It recognises a person's right (data subject rights) to protect their personal data or information by mandating a data controller or processor to process (collect, use, disclose, erase, etc) such personal data or information in accordance with the individual's rights. The Act also established the Data Protection Commission as an independent statutory body to ensure and enforce compliance. ""

The framework is very comprehensive and provides the guideline for the protection of personal data. The Act empowers data subjects with the rights of choice, access, consent, correction of personal data about the data subjects as well as a means of redress. This Act outlines various responsibilities for data controllers such  prohibition to purchase, obtain or disclose personal data and prohibition of sale of personal data.
The Commission also has a web portal where a new user can register, an old user can login and renew and also search for existing information.

Guatemala,GTM,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Guatemala has no specific legal framework for protection of personal data. Guatemala also does not have a regulatory authority that is responsible for controlling the use of personal data, its transfer, processing, commercialisation, and in general terms, its protection. In addition, attempts to issue specific regulation have failed. But there are alternative norms or laws that play a partial role in protection of personal data.

The Political Constitution of the Republic of Guatemala ('the Constitution') recognises privacy and data privacy rights as a constitutional right. (1) Articles one to five of the Political Constitution of the Republic of Guatemala implicitly recognises the right to human dignity and human rights that encompass a right to privacy. Article 23 of the Constitution also recognises dignity and the right to privacy in establishing the inviolability of housing, and Article 24 of the Constitution recognises the inviolability of every individual's correspondence, documents, and book-keeping, and provides that the privacy of correspondence by telephone, radio, cable, and other modes of modern digital technology is guaranteed. Furthermore, Article 30 of the Constitution establishes the public nature of administrative acts and recognises that individuals have the right to obtain public information from the administration. Article 31 of the Constitution determines that any individual has the right to know about all private and personal information recorded in public registries, and has the right to know about the purpose for which such information is recorded, as well as having the right to correct, rectify, and update such information.

Decree No. 57-2008 on the Law on Access to Public Information ('the Law on Access to Public Information'), introduces key data protection concepts such as personal data and sensitive personal data (2). Nevertheless, the subject matter of this law is to secure the access to public information that is in possession of public authorities and obligated entities under the Law on Access to Public Information. The article 64 of the Law on Access to Public Information regulates the commercialisation of personal data and imposes sanctions (fines and imprisonment) to those that distribute, by any means, files containing personal data or sensitive personal data, which do not come from public registries, without the written consent of the data subject.

In a decision issued by the Constitutional Court, Case No. 3552-2014 of 10 February 2015 ('Case 3552-2014'), where the Ombudsman of Human Rights ('the Ombudsman') had filed a case against various private entities accused of gathering and commercialising private information from individuals without their consent. (3) Case 1356-2006 was emblematic in the sense that it was the first case in which the Constitutional Court decided to afford data privacy protection despite the absence of a law regulating this matter in detail. In particular, the Constitutional Court outlined, 'Once a person's right to determine the existence or nonexistence of registries or databases containing his/her personal data is recognised, as well as their right to obtain the rectification, deletion or blocking thereto if the incorrect use of the data may affect his/her intimacy and honour, the manner in which the judicial protection of such rights can be requested must be determined. It is known that in comparative law and in accordance with procedural constitutional modern doctrine, the protection of such rights is done through the action of 'habeas data', which has not been regulated in Guatemala. This case is important and of great relevance because it introduced the right to privacy in Guatemala in the absence of specific data protection legislation.

In the absence of such a law, and while such a situation prevails in the country, this court holds that given the nature and ample scope of the constitutional remedy of legal actions such as 'amparo', amparo is the appropriate constitutional action destined to guarantee the right of every person to access their personal data kept in private or official databases or registries.'
## Sources

(1):  Political Constitution Of The Republic Of Guatemala. Congress of the Republic of Guatemala. https://www.congreso.gob.gt/assets/uploads/secciones/pdf/16e67-constitucion-politica-de-la-republica-de-guatemala.pdf
(2): The Law on Access to Public Information. Congress of the Republic of Guatemala. https://www.congreso.gob.gt/assets/uploads/transparencia/idiomas_pdf/LEY_DE_ACCESO_A_LA_INFORMACION_PUBLICA.pdf

(3): Constitutional Court of Guatemala, decision issued on file 3552-2014 on February 10, 2015. Only available in Spanish at: https://jurisprudencia.cc.gob.gt/portal/Expediente.aspx",2.0,1.0,1.0,28.800000000000004,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,ILDA,Central America,Latin America and the Caribbean,Guatemala City,Guatemala City,14.6133,-90.5353,GT,primary,Gobernanza

The Cybercrime Act of 2018 does cover illegal access to a computer system, illegal interception, illegal data interference, illegal acquisition of data, illegal system interference, and illegal devices, are all offences under the Cybercrime Act. Honduras,HND,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Honduras, there is currently no law in force that regulates the protection of personal data (1). However, efforts have been made in this regard. In 2015, a bill for the Protection of Personal Data was promoted by the then in the National Congress. This project was based on the preliminary project that was presented by the National Institute for Access to Public Information in 2013 with the support of the Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation (AECID).

Currently, the bill is still under debate in the legislative chamber. The last debate took place in April 2018. However, this process has been delayed more than expected, considering that only 19 of the 97 articles contained in the project have been approved.

In the absence of special legislation, personal data in Honduras have at least one protection that is recognized in the Law of the Institute of Access to Public Information, Legislative Decree No. 170 - 2006. In articles 24 to 26 of this law Habeas Data, the protection of personal data, is recognized and the figure of the National Human Rights Commissioner is presented as an office empowered to initiate actions for the protection of personal data; It also establishes a prohibition in which no person can request other personnel who may generate some type of discrimination or put at risk the moral and patrimonial rights of that individual.

Hong Kong,HKG,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Hong Kong, the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance was passed in 1995 and took effect from December 1996, with significant amendments in 2012, which mainly introduced provisions
column2: regarding direct marketing.

column1: Part 6A of the PDPO requires that data users must obtain informed consent before using a data subject's personal data for direct marketing.
The Data Protection Principle (DPP) 6 and Part 5 of the PDPO provides data subjects with the right to request access to and correction of their own personal data.

DPP2 requires data users to take all practicable steps to ensure that personal data is accurate and is not kept longer than is necessary for the fulfilment of the purpose for which the data is used. If you engage a data processor for handling personal data of other persons, you should adopt contractual or other means to ensure that the data processor comply with the mentioned retention requirement.

India,IND,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Information Technology Act, 2000 (the ""IT Act"") read with the Information Technology (Reasonable Security Practices and Procedures and Sensitive Personal Data or Information) Rules, 2011 (the ""SPDI Rules"", together with the IT Act ""Data Protection Laws"") contain specific provisions governing protection of personal data in India.

In 2017, the Supreme Court of India upheld that privacy is a fundamental right, which is entrenched in Article 21 [Right to Life & Liberty] of the Constitution. This led to the formulation of a comprehensive Personal Data Protection Bill 2019 (the PDP Bill). The enactment of the PDP Bill will overhaul the personal data protection and regulatory regime in India. The PDP Bill is currently pending consideration of the Indian Parliament.

Indonesia,IDN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Indonesia does not yet have an integrated and holistic legal framework for protection of personal data. Personal data protection is mentioned across at least 32 different laws and regulations at the moment, some contradicting others (see evidence 1 attached)

The Indonesian government and house of representatives are currently working on a draft of Law on Personal Data Protection that will provide a more integrated and robust legal framework (see evidence 3 attached)
A framework assessed is the Communications and Information Technology Ministerial Regulation No. 20/2016 on protection of personal data in electronic systems.

The ministerial regulation acts as a further explanation/derivative of a higher level regulations that mentions personal data protection: Law No.19/2016 (revision of Law No.11/2008) on electronic information and transactions (article 26) and Government Regulation No.71/2019 on implementation of electronic systems and transactions (article 14).",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,East-West Management Institute Inc. Jamaica,JAM,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Jamaica Data Protection Act (2020) covers all matters relating to the protection of personal data and enforcement of the use of such data (1). Data protection policies are being implemented in the private sector in keeping with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (2018) (2). The GDPR is a European Law that applies to companies once they offer services to persons in Europe.

Jordan,JOR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Jordan lacks a legal framework for protection of personal data. A draft law which recalls the GDPR in terms of data subjects' rights, has been proposed by the government but still not approved by the Parliament. The draft law introduces the right to informed consent and to access and correct data. Although it provides some remedies in case of failure to protect data by public or private bodies, the draft law does not call for the creation of an independent authority.",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Birzeit University,Western Asia,Middle East and North Africa,Amman,Amman,31.9497,35.9328,JO,primary,Gobernanza

Kazakhstan,KAZ,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Kazakhstan is building a strong legislation framework on the protection of personal data. In 2013, the government adopted the Personal data protection law. The main features of the law is establishing the rules for the collection, storage, processing, and protection of personal data(1). The law establishes:

1. Key terms: personal data collection, processing, distribution, and de-personalization. 2. Entities involved in the collection and processing of personal data (personal data owners, owners of databases containing personal data, database operators, third parties); 3. instances in which it is permissible to acquire and process personal data without the owner's consent; 4. obligations for de-personalization of data and subsequent destruction of personal information;  In addition, the Law 'On Informatization' adopted in 2015 provides for the measures to prevent illegal access to digital information (2). The Ministry of Digital Development, Innovation, and Aerospace Industry of the Republic of Kazakhstan is the main authority in the area of personal data protection.
Sources:

column1: Kenya,KEN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The assessment of this indicator has been based on the Laws enacted by the Government of Kenya to regulate the collection and processing of data in Kenya through the Data Protection Act of 2019.

The Act was established by the Parliament of Kenya to develop a comprehensive framework for the provision for the regulation of the processing of personal data, to provide for the rights of data subjects and obligations of data controllers and processors in Kenya.

To give effect to Article 31(c) and (d) of the Constitution; to establish the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner; to make provision for the regulation of the processing of personal data; to provide for the rights of data subjects and obligations of data controllers and processors; and for connected purposes.""
Sources

(1) Data Protection Act.2019. http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/2019/TheDataProtectionAct__No24of2019.pdf",2.0,1.0,1.0,70.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Eastern Africa,Africa,Nairobi,Nairobi,-1.2864,36.8172,KE,primary,Gobernanza

Korea, South,KOR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Korean government enacted the Personal Information Protection Act on March 29, 2011, to unify the legal system related to personal information protection and to strengthen the protection of individual rights and interests(1). Under this Act, not only public institutions but also all persons who process personal information to operate personal information files for business purposes such as the private sector are required to comply with the personal information protection regulations(2).

This Act regulates the scope of personal information protection(Article 2), the establishment of the Personal Information Protection Commission(Article 7 and 8), the establishment of protection standards for each stage such as the collection, use, and provision of personal information(Article 15 to 22), the introduction of the personal information impact assessment system(Article 33), the introduction of the notification and reporting system of the data breach(Article 34), the protection of data subjects' rights(Article 35 to 39), the establishment of a personal information dispute mediation committee and the introduction of a collective dispute mediation system(Article 40 to 50), and reporting on personal information infringement(Article 62)(1).

In addition, the Korean government enacted the Act on the Protection, Use, Etc. of Location Information on January 27, 2005, to protect privacy from the divulging, abuse, and misuse of location information, provide a safe environment for using location information, and activate the use of location information(3)(4).
Sources

Kyrgyzstan,KGZ,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The major framework on protection of personal data is the  Law of the Kyrgyz Republic ""About the information of personal character"", dated April 14, 2008, No. 58
http://cbd.minjust.gov.kg/act/view/ru-ru/202269

The law on protection of personal data contradicts others about openness and transparency. Thus, the law on protection of personal data allows to collect data about financial status, health conditions only with the written permission of the citizens of Kyrgyzstan. However, the law on subsoils dated May 19, 2018 No. 49 requires the publication of information on beneficiaries openly, including personal data.

Latvia,LVA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Article 96 of the Constitution of Latvia establishes the right to privacy (4). Given that the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) delegated to all EU member states to develop national legislation, Latvia's parliament adopted a new law ""Personal Data Processing Law"" (1) that entered into force on July 5, 2018. The law contains provisions that are necessary to ensure the application of the Regulation therefore the scope of the law is the same as the scope of the GDPR (but it does not apply to intelligence agencies). Chapter II of the law specifies Data State Inspectorate as data supervisory authority within the meaning of the GDPR. Data State Inspectorate has published several guidelines and recommendations for citizens (2) on how to exercise their rights granted by law and together with the Ombudsman recommended the government to develop a regulatory framework for video surveillance (3) in 2020 but no amendments have been adopted. National law does not contain specific rules regarding Article 82 of the GDPR about the right to receive compensation in case of damage suffered. However, Section 1775 of the Latvian Civil Law (5) can be applied.

column1: Liberia,LBR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"1) The government passed the National Identification Registry Act in 2011. The purpose of the Act is to provide for a biometric identification system for the country. The law also gave the institution established to administer it the authority to make rules for data protection. As yet, no such rules have been generally promulgated. The director of the Registry made this clear to the researcher in a telephone conversation. He also confirmed that the Registry has no functional website and that its searchable database is only available to a few institutions that use it for verification purposes.
2) Liberia passed its freedom of information law in 2010. The law has very limited provisions on individual data protection.

3) The Ministry of Post and Telecommunication has led efforts to introduce a Cybercrime Act. Those efforts have gone on since 2017 with the last review happening in 2019. The draft Cybercrimes Act is thin on the protection of personal data even though it contains some provisions that could be construed as protective of privacy. The Draft Cybercrimes Bill is currently available in hardcopy only.
1) National Identification Registry Act. 2011. (no URL available)
2) Freedom of Information Act. 2010. http://www.liberianembassyus.org/uploads/documents/Liberia%20Freedom%20of%20Information%20Act%202010x.pdf

3) Cybercrimes Bill. 2018. (no URL available)",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Western Africa,Africa,Monrovia,Monrovia,6.3133,-10.8014,LR,primary,Gobernanza

These are two core legal acts regulating protection of personal data in Lithuania.

Malawi,MWI,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Malawi there are a few  laws that speak to data protection briefly. These laws neither  cover data protection matters   exclusively nor in sufficient detail. The laws touch on consent when  it comes to processing of  personal  data and provide redresses against public institutions that   breach data protection laws. However the laws do not specifically give any provisions addressing algorithmic decision making or cover the protection of location related data.

These absence of such provisions in the current framework indicate that   there is a need for a robust stand alone act solely for data protection especially considering that a lot of personal date is now being collected by a number of public  and private bodies without the necessary safeguards.

There is a  draft   data protection Bill which , once enacted, will empower section 21 of the Malawian constitution which has remained largely inoperative due to the lack of a specific law that details its framework for enforcement. In turn, this will help the government to fulfil its obligation on the protection of rights to privacy (3). However, certain limitations have been pointed out. While Clause 5 exempts processing of personal data, if done by individuals ""solely for personal, recreational or household purposes from the application of the law,"" (4) it does not define the terms ""personal,"" ""recreational"" or ""household"" purposes - this leaves room for abuse of privacy of the data subject. And Clause 14 provides for a penalty in case of breach of confidentiality of a fine of K5,000,000 (USD 6,289) and imprisonment for five years  - an express double punishment that may lead to miscarriage of justice (5).
Sources

(4) Ibid

7) Electronic Transactions and Cyber Security Act",2.0,1.0,1.0,47.6,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Eastern Africa,Africa,Blantyre,Blantyre,-15.7861,35.0058,MW,admin,Gobernanza

Malaysia,MYS,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Personal Data Protection Act 2010 (Act 709) applies to all processing of personal data in the country and applies to the whole country. There is a review on this act in 2020 called the Public Consultation Paper No. 01/2020 – Review of Personal Data Protection Act 2010 (PC01/2020)

Malta,MLT,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Malta's main law concerning a framework for the protection of personal data comes via the Data Protection Act (1). In addition to the safeguards that it provides, it also implements the EU's GDPR regulation (2). In today's modern world where data is being digitalised, the Processing of Personal Data (Electronic Communications Sector) Regulations also cover specific instances of consent, rights to access, and other such scenarios (3). The regulator overseeing data protection in Malta is the Office of the Information and Data Protection Commissioner (IDPC) that tackles wide ranging issues from personal data breaches to assisting with the application of GDPR (4).
1) DATA PROTECTION ACT, Cap. 586, 2018. https://idpc.org.mt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/CAP-586.pdf
2) DATA PROTECTION ACT, Cap. 586, Art2, 2018. https://idpc.org.mt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/CAP-586.pdf
3) PROCESSING OF PERSONAL DATA (ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS SECTOR) REGULATIONS, SL 586.01, 2003. https://legislation.mt/eli/sl/586.1/eng.

4) IDPC, n.d., Our Office, https://idpc.org.mt/our-office/.",2.0,1.0,1.0,90.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Access Info Europe,Southern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Valletta,Valletta,35.8983,14.5125,MT,primary,Gobernanza

Mexico,MEX,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"There are two relevant laws regarding the protection of personal data: The General Law of Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Obliged Subjects (1) and the Federal Law on the Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Individuals (2). The combination of both apply to all the levels and branches of government. I would say the protection of personal data is extensive, as the relevant regulatory framework does not only promote the protection of the data and has been implemented in practice, but it complies with quality requirements such as providing the right of choice / consent of the people, the right to access and / or correct personal data, imposes clear responsibilities on those who guard the information (differentiating between the figuv  vc res of ""charged with"" and ""responsible"" for the data), and provides the right to redress against public and private bodies that violate data privacy.
Additionally, these regulations contemplate the procedures to anonymize before publication, which guarantees that sensitive and personally identifiable data are eliminated prior to any publication.

In fact, the right to the protection of personal data is only limited by exception provided in the aforementioned laws and is stipulated in the Political Constitution of the Mexican United States (3), in its article 16 as a fundamental right or individual guarantee that cannot be waived. Therefore, sanction mechanisms are provided for the infringement of personal data, ranging from warnings, to economic, civil and even criminal sanctions.

The autonomous body for the protection of personal data is the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data (4), and constantly issues consultation material to facilitate understanding of the concept of personal data, disclose best practices on privacy and confidentiality notices and what to do if you consider a potential vulnerability of this right. These materials exist for both the private and public sectors and range from the best Guides of self-regulation schemes in the field of personal data protection to suggested minimum criteria for contracting computing services in the cloud that involve the processing of personal data.
## Sources
(1) The General Law of Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Obliged Subjects http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGPDPPSO.pdf
(2) Federal Law on the Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Individuals http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LFPDPPP.pdf
(3) http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/ref/cpeum.htm

(4) http://inicio.ifai.org.mx/SitePages/ifai.aspx",2.0,1.0,1.0,64.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,ILDA,Central America,Latin America and the Caribbean,Mexico City,Mexico City,19.4333,-99.1333,MX,primary,Gobernanza

Moldova,MDA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Law on personal data protection was adopted in 2011, undergoing some changes over the years. This law creates the legal framework necessary for the application of Directive 95/46 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 October 1995 on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data. The purpose of this law is to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of the natural person with regard to the processing of personal data, in particular the right to the inviolability of private, family, and private life. (1)

However, there is always a debate regarding data protection and personal data that can be of public interest. The national authorities often interpret in a restrictive manner the provisions enshrined in the Law on the Protection of Personal Data with regard to journalists, which have the constitutional task of informing the public on matters of public interest. Information providers often do not apply the essential criteria of balancing the right to the protection of personal data and the right to freedom of expression and information. In the text of the Law on the protection of personal data, there is no definition of personal data related to the category of information of public interest and personal data that may become information of public interest. (2)
Sources:
(1) https://www.legis.md/cautare/getResults?doc_id=126192&lang=ro

(2) http://media-azi.md/sites/default/files/PROTECTIA%20DATELOR%20CU%20CARACTER%20PERSONAL%20VS%20LIBERTATEA%20DE%20EXPRIMARE%20SI%20INFORMARE_0.pdf",2.0,1.0,1.0,80.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,IDFI Georgia,Eastern Europe,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Chisinau,Chisinau,47.0228,28.8353,MD,primary,Gobernanza

Mongolia,MNG,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Law of Mongolia on Personal Privacy (1) is enacted in 1995. As the main legislation, the law covers and considers five types of secrecy including secrecy of correspondence; secrecy of health information; secrecy of property; secrecy of family; and other secrecy, which is defined by laws. However, there is a lack of a framework that provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent or requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches. Also, it lacks a section that addresses algorithmic decision-making and the protection of data. Due to the insufficient available sections to regulate, the Draft Law on Protection of Personal Data was issued by parliament members, with an invitation for public comments(3) in February 2021. Although the draft law on the Protection of Personal Data is in the process of being approved, the new law includes various sections to fill the gaps in the existing law.
Sources:

It is available at the official website of the Data Protection National Commission (Commission Nationale de Protection des Données Personnelles). (1)

Mozambique,MOZ,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Mozambique does not yet have a law on data protection. Since 2020 the country has started to debate on the matter (1), but at this moment it is not clear at what stage the process is. It is expected that the debate will restart to prepare a draft law on data protection (2).
