Namibia,NAM,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Different, isolated framework on data protection of personal data exists in different sectors according to DLA Piper, a global law firm operating through various separate and distinct legal entities.To a certain extent that protection held water until the digital evolution where the application of data protection online isn't guaranteed under existing laws and does not comprehensively offer protection personal data anymore.

Hence, the extent of the relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance do not provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data in a digital age and doesn't comprehend/promote operations under the open data framework.",1.0,0.5,1.0,45.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Southern Africa,Africa,Windhoek,Windhoek,-22.57,17.0836,,primary,Gobernanza

Nepal,NPL,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Privacy Act, 2075 (2018) [1] of Nepal overall covers the protection of personal data within the public bodies but it fails to bind the private sectors from misusing the data as private sectors are not incorporated [2]. Also, the current applicable laws do not prescribe provisions for notification in the situation of a data breach and the emerging issue of algorithmic decision-making [3]. Details regarding the consent, responsibilities for data holders, rights to correct, and rights of redress have been defined clearly.
[1] Individual Privacy Act, 2018 (2075): http://www.pioneerlaw.com/news/individual-privacy-act-2018-2075
[2] Introduction To The Privacy Act 2018: https://www.neupanelegal.com/news-detail/introduction-to-the-privacy-act-2018.html

[3] Nepal: Data Protection Overview: https://www.dataguidance.com/notes/nepal-data-protection-overview",2.0,1.0,1.0,50.40000000000001,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,East-West Management Institute Inc. (EWMI),Southern Asia,South and East Asia,Kathmandu,Kathmandu,27.71,85.32,NP,primary,Gobernanza

Netherlands,NLD,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679)(GDPR, AVG in Dutch), which has direct effect in all EU-countries, and the Dutch General Data Protection Regulation Implementation Act (GDPRIA, UAVG in Dutch). The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data (Article 2). The definitions of data 'controllers' and 'processors' cover all private and public sectors. (1)

Chapter 6 of the GDPR dictates that each member state should have an independent supervisory authority ensuring and monitoring the application of the regulation, 'in order to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons in relation to processing and to facilitate the free flow of personal data within the Union' (Article 51, 52). Among other things, this authority monitors data protection, advises legislative and administrative government bodies, and handles complaints lodged by data subjects, organizations or others (Article 57(1.f)(2)). The Dutch Data Protection Authority (DPA) is called the Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens. The mentioned fundamental rights are Article 8 European Convention on Human Rights and Article 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental rights. (2)

Data processors (when they are a public body, or when processing data is their main activity or they do it on a large scale) need to appoint a data protection officer, who registers with and reports to the national authority, and is responsible for GDPR-compliance. This is implemented thorugh the GDPRIA. (3) Furthermore, Article 68 of the GDPR established the European Data Protection Board, which is composed of the heads of the supervisory authority of member states. It is responsible for the consistent application of the DDPR. It's tasks consist of monitoring, advising the EU Commission, and issuing guidelines, recommendations and best practices for data processors, governments and supervisory authorities (Article 70 GDPR). Also it issues opinions when national authorities take certain measures and settles disputes between or within national authorities (Articles 64 & 65). (4)

Article 77 of the GDPR gives data subjects the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority and Article 78 contains the right to an effective judicial remedy against this supervisory authority. Article 79 adds a right to an effective judicial remedy against a data controller or processor. Together these articles ensure an effective right to redress. (5)

Data controllers have to comply with the core principles and responsibilities set out in article 5 GDPR. I.a. taking steps to ensure personal information is updated and accurate; limiting access to personal data in accordance with its intended use; only transferring data to third-parties if there are assurances they will also respect data protection rights; destroying or anonymising data after it is no longer needed for its original intended use. The Controller is responsible for ensuring third parties comply to the principles as well (Article 5 Paragraph 2, and Article 4, Paragraph 1). Rules related to  transferring of data are set out in Chapter 5. (6)

Data controllers and processors must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to existing security  risks (Article 32 GDPR). The GDPR requires a personal data breach to be notified, without undue delay (max. 72 hours) by the controller to its supervisory authority, and for more serious breaches to be notified to the affected data subjects as well (Article 33 & 34). Article 4 defines a data breach as a 'breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed'. (7)

The framework contains specific rules covering algorithmic decision-making. To 'ensure fair and transparent processing', the controller has to provide a data subject with (access to) information on the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, and meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject (Article 13(2.f), 14(2.g) and 15(1.h) GDPR). Article 22 GDPR formulates a prohibition on fully automated individual decision-making that is based on profiling, if it has a legal or otherwise significant impact on the data subject. (8) According to the Dutch DPA, this means: 'important decisions should not be made by an algorithm alone, without human intervention'. (9) However, Article 22 provides three exceptions. Automated decision making is allowed when it is: necessary for entering into or performing a contract, authorized by EU or Member State law, or the data subject has given their explicit (opt-in) consent. When decisions are taken on the basis of the first and second option, the data subject also has the right to obtain human intervention, to contest the decision, and to express his or her point of view. The Dutch DPA has used the second option to implement exceptions to the prohibition in Article 40 of the GDPRIA, which states that the GDPR does not apply if the automated individual decision-making, other than based on profiling, is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject or for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest. (10) So for instance when awarding study or child allowances. (11)

The GDPR does not contain specific rules on location data, but it does consider this to be personal information, so as long as it is not anonymized is falls under the protection of the regulation. The ePrivacy Directive (Directive (EU) 2002/58/EC), which will soon be replaced by the e-privacy directive, handles data protection in the context of telecommunication, so it protects location data related to users' terminal equipment. (12) Also, the European Data Protection Board that oversees the GDPR implementation, on the 21ste of April 2021, issued guidelines (on the basis of Article 70(1.e) GDPR), for the use of location data and contact tracing tools in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak. It has developed rules on the data, the purpose of use, security, et cetera. However, the guidelines are not binding. (13)

No other additions or changes to the legal framework have been made. However, in March 2020 the Dutch DPA announced it would be making some adjustments to its approach, in light of Covid-19. They wrote that the DPA is ""giving governments and companies room to focus on combating corona during the corona crisis. For example, organizations will be given more time to respond to questions from the AP where necessary, and the DPA will give initiatives to protect public health plenty of room. But the regulator will continue to intervene where privacy is truly at risk."" For example, they allow some  health care facillities that do not have a way to make secure video calls to patient, to use consumer apps like FaceTime or Skype. (14)

(13) EDPB, Guidelines 04/2020 on the use of location data and contact tracing tools in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak, April 21st 2020, https://edpb.europa.eu/sites/default/files/files/file1/edpb_guidelines_20200420_contact_tracing_covid_with_annex_en.pdf.

(14) Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens, 'AP geeft organisaties meer tijd vanwege coronacrisis', March 20th 2020, https://autoriteitpersoonsgegevens.nl/nl/nieuws/ap-geeft-organisaties-meer-tijd-vanwege-coronacrisis.",2.0,1.0,1.0,85.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Access Info Europe,Western Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Tilburg,Tilburg,51.55,5.0833,NL,minor,Gobernanza

New Zealand,NZL,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The 2020 Privacy Act, which applies across New Zealand and covers public and private data holders, came into force on 1 December 2020(1). It ""affords New Zealanders better privacy protections, and organisations and businesses greater obligations when handling personal information"" and ""gives the Privacy Commissioner greater powers to ensure organisations and businesses comply with the Act"".(2) It sets out twelve privacy  information principles covering rights of choice or consent, rights to access and correct personal data, rights of redress and notification of data breaches and responsibilities for data holders(3). It also gives the Privacy Commissioner the power to issue codes of practice that become part of the law. These codes modify the operation of the Privacy Act and set rules for specific industries, organisations, or types of personal information(4).

Complaints, investigations, and proceedings are set out in Part 5 (5). The Privacy Act does not cover location-related data, other than allowing law enforcement authorities to reveal location for vehicles of interest, missing persons (for fines enforcement), and records of prisoners(6). Privacy, ethics and human rights are safeguarded in the government's voluntary Algorithm Charter for Aotearoa New Zealand to which 26 government agencies have signed up(7). This Charter complements the 2018 Principles for the safe and effective use of data and analytics(8). No impact assessment of the Charter has been completed in this survey period. The Privacy Commissioner has published a very extensive range of publications describing the Privacy Act 2020(9). On 6 July 2021 the Government announced it would implement a new legislative framework for a consumer data right following public consultation on a 2020 Discussion Paper(10), (11). New Zealand Geospatial Research and Development Priorities and Opportunities 2016 – 2020 states that obstacles to increasing the uptake and use of geospatial information include concerns about data privacy, data ownership, the liability for the use of data and data confidentiality(12).

Paraguay,PRY,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Paraguay lacks legislation on the comprehensive protection of personal data or data privacy. The Constitution does not address protection of personal data directly. Existing legislation on personal data and current proposals invoke Art. 33 of the Constitution, which talks about the right to intimacy. The Constitution's Art. 45 ""Of rights and guarantees not enunciated"" establishes that the lack of legislation cannot deny rights and guarantees inherent to the human nature. Habeas data appears on Art. 135 (1).

However, in October 2020 a bill was enacted by Congress on the subject of personal credit data (2). TEDIC, an NGO that specializes in data privacy and Internet governance, emphasized that said bill focused on privacy of credit data, not on the protection of personal data (3). Late in April 2021, the Coalition of Personal Data in Paraguay (Coalición de Datos Personales en Paraguay) presented a bill to Congress on a comprehensive framework for the protection of personal data in Paraguay (4).

The National Emergency Law (6524/2020) enacted due to the COVID-19 pandemic stated in its Art. 49: ""... to keep the security and protection of personal data that is collected, stored, processed and/or transmitted through technological systems or mediums implemented due to this emergency situation"" (5).
Sources:

(3) TEDIC. 2020. ""Ley de Datos Personales no es una Ley de Datos Crediticios"". Accessed May 16, 2020. https://www.tedic.org/ley-de-datos-personales-no-es-una-ley-de-datos-crediticios/

(4) TEDIC. 2021. ""El Congreso Nacional da entrada oficial al Proyecto de Ley de Protección de Datos Personales"". https://www.tedic.org/el-congreso-nacional-da-entrada-oficial-al-proyecto-de-ley-de-proteccion-de-datos-personales/

Peru,PER,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Currently the country has a comprehensive framework for the protection of personal data that was approved in 2011, the so-called Law No. 29733 (1), which aims to guarantee the fundamental right to the protection of personal data, provided for in the Political Constitution of Peru, which is currently in force and in turn has a regulation of law (2) that provides for its mandatory compliance in all public and private entities. Likewise, it is stipulated that the Ministry of Justice and Human Rights is the National Authority for the Protection of Personal Data (3), which must comply with and enforce compliance with the regulations in force on the protection of personal data. And with regard to the protection of the content of the information of those involved, there is the National Registry for the Protection of Personal Data (4), which has information on public or private personal data banks in order to exercise the rights of access to information, correction, and other modifications in accordance with the Law.

column1: Philippines,PHL,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Republic Act No. 10173 or the Data Privacy Act of 2012, along with its Implementing Rules and Regulations and the Advisory Opinions being released by the National Privacy Commission, provide a detailed framework for protecting personal data.

However, what is written in policy does not necessarily reflect in practice, as leaks of COVID-19 patient information (1) remain with impunity, and exacting accountability in relation to massive data breaches in the past years remain unreported.

Portugal,PRT,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Portugal has got a decent framework supported by different pieces of legislation with regards to  protection of personal data. Established as a constitutional right, protection of personal data is ruled by the following laws:
(1) Article 35 of the Portuguese Constitution
(2) Law 58/2019 which ensures the implementation at national level of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

(3) Law 59/2019 ensures the implementation at national level of Regulation (UE) 2016/680 on the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data.
(4) Law n.º 41/2004 ensures the implementation at national level of Regulation (UE) 2002/58/EC on the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector

In 2021, Portugal enacted (5) Law n.º 27/2021 Portuguese Charter of Human Rights in the Digital Age which further supports protection of personal data in the country. However, this was not taken into account as they fall outside the formal evaluation period of this study , ending in May 1, 2021.

Romania,ROU,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In 2016, the Regulation on the protection of personal data entered into force throughout the European Union, therefore Romania is a state that applies Regulation 2016/679, together with Law 190/2018 on measures to implement Regulation (EU) 2016 / 679. The Romanian public institution that has the general competence in the field of personal data protection is the National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data (1). The Regulation on the protection of personal data is one of the most complex normative acts in the world on this subject and deals with important issues, such as the obligation to consent before data processing, ensuring important rights regarding confidentiality and needs, while addressing the responsibilities of personal data controllers. The regulation applies to both the public and private sectors, including civil society organizations (2).

Regarding compliance with the Regulation during the Covid-19 pandemic, on the 21st of April 2020, the European Data Protection Board adopted Guidelines 4/2020 on the use of location data and contact tracing tools in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak, that established for the tracking apps not to involve the use of location data, but only proximity data (3).

In 2019, the National Authority received a total of 6193 complaints, intimation and notifications regarding security incidents, based on which 912 investigations were opened. As a result of the investigations carried out, 28 fines were applied in a total amount of 2,339,291.75 lei (meaning approximately 475,461.12 euros). In addition, 134 warnings were applied and 128 corrective measures were ordered (4). The activity report for 2020 is not yet on the institution's website, but it would be interesting to follow the number of fines granted during the pandemic.
Sources

(1): LAW no. 102/2005 on the set up, organisation and functioning of the National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing – Republished; https://www.dataprotection.ro/servlet/ViewDocument?id=172
(2): REGULATION (EU) 2016/679; https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:32016R0679&from=RO#d1e1807-1-1
(3): Guidelines 04/2020 on the use of location data and contact tracing tools in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak; https://www.dataprotection.ro/servlet/ViewDocument?id=1878

(4): The National Supervisory Authority For Personal Data Processing annual Report 2019.",2.0,1.0,1.0,100.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Access Info Europe,Eastern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Bucharest,Bucharest,44.4325,26.1039,RO,primary,Gobernanza

Russia,RUS,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Work with personal data in Russia is governed by the Federal Law of July 27, 2006, N 152-FZ On Personal Data [1]. This law regulates the relations associated with the processing of personal data, which is carried out by state bodies, legal entities, and individuals. The purpose of the law is to ensure the protection of human and civil rights and freedoms in the processing of his personal data, including the protection of privacy rights, personal and family secrets. State bodies, the Bank of Russia, and local self-government bodies, within their powers, can adopt normative legal acts on certain issues pertaining to the processing of personal data.

In general, the processing of personal data requires the consent of the subject of personal data. Operators and other persons who have access to personal data are required to ensure the confidentiality of data, that is, not disclose to third parties or disseminate personal data without the consent of the personal data subject. Information on the subject of personal data must be deleted at any time from publicly available personal data sources at the request of the personal data subject or by a court or other authorized government agency.

The subject of personal data decides to provide his personal data and agrees to their processing in written or electronic form. This form should contain the following fields (full list in Article 9 of the law): name and surname, address, passport number of the personal data subject, name and surname or the name and address of the operator, the purpose of processing personal data, the list of personal data, method of withdrawal of consent, the signature of the subject.

Chapter 3 of the law contains a list of the rights of the subject of personal data, these include: the right of the subject of personal data to access his personal data; the rights of subjects of personal data when processing their personal data in order to promote goods, works, services on the market, and also for the purposes of political agitation; rights of subjects of personal data when making decisions on the basis of exclusively automated processing of their personal data; the right to appeal against the actions or omissions of the operator.

Chapter 4 of the law contains the duties of the operator, namely: the duties of the operator in the collection of personal data; measures to ensure that the operator performs the duties; measures to ensure the safety of personal data when processing them; the duties of the operator when referring to the subject of personal data; duties of the operator to eliminate violations of the legislation; notification of the processing of personal data; persons responsible for organizing the processing of personal data in organizations.

Chapter 5 of the law contains information on the authorized body for the protection of the rights of subjects of personal data and information on the responsibility for violating the requirements of the law.

To date, when a person completes any contracts or documents, for example, at a university, a hospital (including commercial laboratories), a government agency, etc., the ""Consent to the Processing of Personal Data"" form is additionally issued and must be completed. It is also filled in electronically, for example, when a person registers on the site, fills out a form, or draws up a ticket for the event.

Since July 1, 2017, legislation in the field of personal data has been significantly tightened. Tightening affected the owners of sites and agencies, their developing and servicing. The minimal (incomplete) list of actions [2] of site owners in order to avoid fines and blocking consists of the following items:

1. Under each form of data entry on sites and mobile applications (registration form, application, feedback, etc.), place the text ""By clicking on the button, I consent to the processing of personal data"", where the text ""consent to the processing of personal data ""is a link to the document itself. Instead of consent, you can use a single public offer, but it will need to register for what purposes, what data is being processed. In this case, it is necessary to store logs to prove to the authorized body that a particular user actually visited the site and left his personal data there.
2. The site owner must approve the Policy on the processing of personal data by the order and place it in his office, on the site, and in the mobile application in the public domain.

3. Transfer the site to the territory of the Russian Federation and learn from the technical support of the hosting provider or data center the address of the location of your server (find out right up to the building).
4. Specify an email where an individual can apply to ensure that his personal data is deleted, blocked and where he can ask a question about personal data.

5. The Agency and the site owner must submit a notice on the processing of personal data to the authorized body and, among other things, specify the addresses of the location of the personal data bases and the list of personal data contained therein.

6. The Agency and the site owner, in case the agency has access to personal data from applications, databases or simply attracts customers, it is necessary to conclude an agreement on the security of personal data, which will indicate which personal data can be processed, for what purposes and what actions with them can be performed.
The legal requirement for the processing of personal data on servers located on the territory of Russia led to the blocking of the Linkedin and Slideshare in Russia [3].

Despite the rather rigid and detailed legislation on personal data in Russia, there have been cases of leakage of the personal data of citizens. For example, in the summer of 2017, one of the users announced, that 17.7 thousand people were leaked from the Pension Fund of Russia in Moscow and the Moscow Region [4]. He received an e-mail from the pension fund, which contained a file with a table in which the user had to find a line with his name using the search and enter data. According to him, the employees of the pension fund did not consider that the filter of the Excel table allows to show all the lines.
In 2016, Infowatch (a company that deals with data security analytics) recorded that 128 million sensitive data records were compromised in Russia [5].

In addition, in accordance with Article 24 of the Russian Constitution, the collection, storage, use, and dissemination of information on a person's private life without his consent is not allowed. Bodies of state power and local self-government bodies, their officials are obliged to provide everyone with an opportunity to get acquainted with documents and materials directly affecting his rights and freedoms, unless otherwise provided by law.

[5] https://www.rbc.ru/newspaper/2017/06/08/5937ddda9a79471a1683d2a2",2.0,1.0,1.0,32.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,InfoCulture Russia,Eastern Europe,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Moscow,Moscow,55.7558,37.6172,RU,primary,Gobernanza

Rwanda,RWA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"It is by October 2020 that Rwanda has started to move to tighten rules that govern how personal data and privacy is handled, following a new draft law on data protection and privacy that was approved by the cabinet in the same year(1);

While the Draft Law will regulate the obligations of data controllers and processors, as well as afford data subjects general rights that protect their personal information, it does not establish a national data protection authority(2);
The National Data Revolution Policy recommends the review process to harmonize laws for protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and privacy (3);
However, there are other laws that deal directly or indirectly with data privacy and/or data protection. The list includes:
Article 23 of the Constitution of Rwanda guarantees the right to privacy as a fundamental right (4);

Information and Communication Technologies Law No. 24/2016: promulgated in 2016 in order to regulate electronic communications, information society, the broadcasting sector, and the postal sector (5);

Law No. 18/2010 of 12/05/2010 relating to Electronic Messages, Electronic Signatures and Electronic Transactions: promulgated in 2010 to regulate the electronic collection of personal information (6);
The National Bank of Rwanda has issued the Regulation no 02/2018 of 24/01/2018 on Cybersecurity(7);

Furthermore, it is noted that the Rwanda Utilities Regulatory Authority published a Draft Regulation Governing the Use of Personal Data in Rwanda in 2019 to enable citizens to exercise their right to data privacy and have enforceable recourse should the right be infringed upon (8).

Senegal,SEN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The legal framework of data protection is governed by the law 2008-12 on the protection of personal data, the penal code that punishes cybersecurity violations, and the regulatory texts of the African Union, the Uemoa and the Ecowas. Our analysis is based primarily on the reading of the 2008 law.

column1: Sierra Leone,SLE,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In June 2021, Sierra Leone passed the cybersecurity bill to address some of the regulatory gaps in the country's digital space. Notwithstanding this progressive move, the said bill does not adequately address issues of 'choice and consent', duties of data holders, and redress mechanisms for data breaches. Other existing laws including Section 22 of the country's Constitution also only partially address data privacy or protection needs (1). While many institutions and businesses develop internal policies to enhance data protection and privacy, these policies cannot be said to have the full force of the law.
Sources
(1) Constitution of Sierra Leone Act No. 6, Section 22,1991. https://sierralii.org/sl/legislation/act/1991/6-0

Slovakia,SVK,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Slovakia is bound by the EU Regulation 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (General Data Protection Regulation,""GDPR""). (1)
Slovakia also adopted Act No. 18/2018 Coll. (the ""Slovak Data Protection Act"") on the protection of personal data, which implemented the GDPR, and amended certain acts. (2)
Therefore, the overall data protection framework in Slovakia is currently very encompassing.

In response to the pandemic, the government passed an Amendment to the Telecommunications Act which allowed the disclosure of data from telecommunication operators to the Office of Public Health of the Slovak Republic. However, the Constitutional Court of the Slovak Republic later decided to suspend the effectiveness of parts of the law that were too vague or did not provide sufficient safeguards against the possible misuse of personal data by public authorities. (3), (4)

(1) European Parliament. 2016. South Africa,ZAF,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The POPIA (1) and the PAIA (2) comprehensively provide frameworks for the protection of personal information as provided in the justifications given under each response. South Africa had to develop a comprehensive framework through the POPIA as the government sought to facilitate the participation of the country's industry in the growing global electronic trade (3). The South African Law Commission was tasked with investigating the country's privacy and data protection policy. The commission's investigation resulted in a report in 2009 in which the recommendation was that privacy and information protection be regulated by a general statute (4). The POPIA was then signed into law in 2013 and eventually enacted into practice on the 1st of July in 2020 (5). Public and private entities were given a year to fully comply with the POPIA by 01 July 2021 (5). The instruments for facilitating the protection of personal information are in place in South Africa. However, it is still quite early to assess how effective they are.
Sources:

Spain,ESP,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"In Spain there is a framework with the force of law that regulates the protection of personal data. The Spanish Constitution, article 18.4 (1), includes the protection of natural persons in relation to the processing of personal data as a fundamental right, which states that ""the law shall limit the use of information technology to guarantee the citizens personal and family privacy and the full exercise of their rights"".

As a member state of the European Union, the General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) (2) is applicable in Spain. This Regulation (hereinafter RGPD) is a European Union law that entered into force in 2016 and, after a two-year transition period, became directly applicable in all Member States of the Union European.
In addition, Spain has its own data protection law, organic law 3/2018, of December 5, on the Protection of Personal Data and Guarantee of Digital Rights (3) (hereinafter LOPDGDD).
According to the analysis carried out by DLA Piper on the regulatory framework regarding privacy and data protection (4), Spain has a ""heavy"" regulatory framework.

The data protection regulatory framework establishes the right of the interested parties to give their consent to the processing of their personal data. The GDPR article 6.1 a) (2) establishes that the data processing will be lawful when the interested party gives their consent for one or more purposes and article 7 regulates the conditions for consent. In the LOPDGDD article 6 (3) the consent of the interested party is regulated.

Although, as stated, the consent of the interested party is a basis of legality for the treatment of the data, it should be noted that the GDPR (2) establishes other bases of legality, such as legitimate interest or compliance with a legal obligation. Therefore, the interested parties must normally grant consent for the processing of their data, as long as the legality of the treatment is not one of the others mentioned in article 6 of the aforementioned regulation.

The existing regulatory framework for the protection of personal data includes the right of the interested parties to access and rectify their data. The GDPR article 15 (2) includes the right of access of the Interested Party, establishing that the interested party ""will have the right to obtain from the data controller confirmation of whether or not personal data concerning them are being processed and, in such case, the right of access to personal data and the following information: the purposes of the treatment; the categories of personal data in question ... ""

The LOPDGDD article 13 (3) reinforces the right of access establishing that ""the right of access of the affected party will be exercised in accordance with the provisions of article 15 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679"".
Regarding the right of rectification, the GDPR article 16 (2) establishes that the interested party has the right to have inaccurate personal data that concerns them rectified.
In the LOPDGDD article 14 (3), the right to rectification recognizes the exercise of this right contained in article 16 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

The obligations and responsibilities of the data holders are mainly included in the GDPR Article 5.1 (2). Section b) establishes the obligation to limit the purpose ""personal data will be collected for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes"" and section c) complements this principle, establishing that ""personal data will be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed."" From these two sections, the responsibility of the data holders to limit access to personal data in accordance with its purpose.

In section d) it establishes that personal data will be ""exact and, if necessary, updated"". This responsibility to keep accurate and up-to-date information is also set out in the LOPDGDD article 4 (3) which establishes the accuracy of the data ""In accordance with article 5.1.d) of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 the data will be exact and, if necessary, updated"".

The obligation to destroy or anonymize the data once the conservation period has elapsed is contained in GDPR article 5.1 section e) (2), which establishes limitation of the conservation period: ""maintained in a way that allows the identification of the interested parties for no longer than is necessary for the purposes of processing personal data"". In addition, article 32 of the same regulation, regarding the security of the treatment establishes that those responsible for the treatment will apply appropriate technical and organizational measures to guarantee a level of security appropriate and where appropriate, includes, among others, pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data ...

The principles relating to data transfers are found in articles 44-46 of the GDPR (2) and in article 40 of the LOPDGDD (3). The articles of the GDPR establish that transfers to a third country or organization may be made if they guarantee an adequate level of data protection, this obligation is also included in art. 40 of LOPDGDD (3), which establishes that data transfers will be governed by the provisions of Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

The existing regulatory framework regulates the right of the interested parties to report and initiate proceedings against public and private organizations in cases where data protection regulations are not respected. In accordance with the provisions of articles 51 and 52 of the GDPR (2), in Spain there is an independent control authority: the Spanish Data Protection Agency, before which the interested parties have the right to file claims, as established in article 77 of the GDPR (2).

The Spanish Data Protection Agency is established as a competent and independent control body in the LOPDGDD article 44.1 (3). This same law regulates in Title VIII the procedures in the case of possible data protection regulation violations.

The GDPR articles 33 and 34 (2) establish the obligation for organizations (public and private) that act as data controllers to notify the competent Control Authority of personal data breaches when it is probable that they constitute a risk to the citizens' rights.

There are other regulatory provisions that require reporting security breaches to the competent control authority (Spanish Data Protection Agency in the case of Spain), such as that of Law 9/2014, of May 9, General Telecommunications Article 41 (5) that obliges operators of electronic communications services available to the public to notify violations of personal data.

The LOPDGDD articles 73 and 74 (3) include as infractions the breach to notify the data protection authority of a personal data security violations in accordance with the provisions of the GDPR article 33 (2).

The Spanish Agency for Data Protection, the competent national authority, has prepared a guide for the notification of personal data breaches (6), which aims to guide those responsible for the processing of personal data in the fulfillment of their notification obligations.

The GDPR (2) seems to cover the protection of location-related data as it is considered to be personal data, as detailed in the GDPR, article 4.1. However, it should be mentioned that although location data is included in the definition of personal data, the said regulation does not include a definition of Location Data.

The GDPR article 22 (2), specifically addresses profiling and automated individual decision-making, stating that ""the data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her""

EDPB Guidelines on Automated individual decision-making and Profiling for the purposes of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (7) clarify the concepts of automated individual decision-making and profiling, and aid in the understanding of current regulations on this subject.

Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have not been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response. The GDPR Recital 46 (2) explicitly recognizes the legal basis for the lawful processing of personal data in exceptional cases, such as the control of epidemics and their spread. Health data is classified as special categories of data, prohibiting its treatment unless it can be covered by any of the exceptions included in article 9.2. of the said regulation.

The Spanish Data Protection Agency published a report on data processing in relation to COVID-19 (8), in which it specified that the processing of personal data in health emergency situations continues to be treated in accordance with the personal data protection regulation.

Decree 43/2021 (9), chapter III, on security of networks and information systems outlines the notification procedure of a cyber-incident and in article 9 the notification obligations provided to the Spanish Data Protection Agency.

The ""cookies"" and eprivacy laws should also be considered, Decree 13/2012 of March 30, 2012, (10) reflecting the European Directive of 2009, modifies article 22 Law 34/2002, article 22 on services of the information society and electronic commerce (LSSI) requires the users consent for ""cookies"" that store information on the user's equipment and allow access to it; devices that can facilitate web browsing but whose use can reveal aspects of the private sphere of users, making it important that users are adequately informed and have mechanisms that allow them to preserve their privacy. And Royal Decree 424/2005, of April 15, (11) which approves the Regulation on the conditions for the provision of electronic communications services, universal service and the protection of users.

Sweden,SWE,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) (GDPR) (1) is a European Union law which entered into force in 2016 and, following a two year transition period, became directly applicable law in all Member States of the European Union on 25 May 2018, without requiring implementation by the EU Member States through national law. Taiwan,TWN,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Taiwan government has a law about the protection of personal data (The Personal Data Protection Act) [1]. However, the exceptions have been used and expanded liberally during the COVID-19 pandemic, with the government citing an emergency situation [2].

There is no requirement to inform about data breaches. During the COVID-19 pandemic, there was an accusation using an existing law (Communication Security and Surveillance Act (CSSA)) in order to bypass the need for permission in order to use the CDC's SMS contact tracing system for criminal investigation, but the accusation was later denied.[2]

The Government of Taiwan ('the Government') has submitted its application to the EU for an adequacy decision pursuant to the General Data Protection Regulation and continues to dialog with EU in this regard. Meanwhile, the Government is evaluating whether the PDPA needs to be further amended in order to further align the PDPA with the GDPR.[3]

However, without an independent data protection agency, there is a gap between the PDPA and the GDPR, and the potential for breaches of privacy is higher.[4] The government indicates that this is upcoming for 2022.
[1] National Development Council. Amended 2015. Personal Data Protection Act. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=I0050021
[2] Chuan-Feng Wu. June 2021. COVID-19 and Data Privacy Challenges in Taiwan. https://lexatlas-c19.org/covid-19-and-data-privacy-challenges-in-taiwan/
[3] Onetrust Data Guidance. 2021. Taiwan Data Protection Overview. https://www.dataguidance.com/notes/taiwan-data-protection-overview.

[4] Taiwan Human Rights Promotion Organization. 2018. Where to find a specialized agency. https://www.tahr.org.tw/news/2268.",2.0,1.0,1.0,49.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,East-West Management Institute Inc. Tajikistan,TJK,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Law No. 1537, adopted on 3 August 2018, On Personal Data Protection is the main regulatory framework in place governing the gathering and protection of personal data (1). The law lays out the guidelines for gathering, storing, and managing personal data across the country of Tajikistan.

The Law is explicit regarding the need of the subjects of the data to provide consent regarding its gathering. Article 22 (along with several provisions in the other articles) guarantees the subjects the rights to access the information, request corrections in case of incorrect or misleading information, although no formalized methods for such requests are provided in the Law. Article 25 lays out the responsibilities of the data holders, while Article 26 indicates that violations of these guidelines will result in the data holders being held responsible in accordance with the rest of Tajikistan's legislation. The Law itself does not outline the punitive measures in its text.
Sources:
1) The Law No. 1537, adopted on 3 August 2018, On Personal Data Protection

Thailand,THA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Personal Data Protection Act is comparable to the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Although it was originally published in May of 2019, the enforcement of the PDPA has seen two postponements. The data protection obligations under the PDPA generally apply to all organisations that collect, use, or disclose personal data in Thailand or of Thai residents, regardless of whether they are formed or recognised under Thai law, and whether they are resident or have a business presence in Thailand. Key aspects of the PDPA include: data processing, data collection, data storage, and data consent protocols.
PDPA will not be enforced against the following organisations and businesses between May 27, 2020-May 31, 2021:

Trinidad and Tobago,TTO,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Data protection Act of 2011 (1) provides a robust framework for Data Protection of individuals in Trinidad and Tobago.  It was legitimized in 2012 (2), and since then has been the governing legislation.

With the advent of Covid-19 the government found it necessary to move away from the Act by publishing data of Individuals who were affected by the disease.  It fact,  a list of persons purportedly under quarantine, together with their personal contact information, was widely circulated on social media. This contradicted the common law principles of confidentiality, and doctor-patient confidentiality in particular (3). To support this move away from the Act, The Public Health [2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)] (No. 8) Regulations, 2020  regulation  was proclaimed (4).
Sources:
1. Data protection Act, 2011.  Chapter  22:04.  https://rgd.legalaffairs.gov.tt/laws2/Alphabetical_List/lawspdfs/22.04.pdf

3.  COVID-19, Privacy and Data Protection. http://trinidadlaw.com/covid-19-privacy-and-data-protection/

4. This study covered the monitoring of the activities and services provided by The high authority for personal data protection, for the period from May 1, 2019 to May 1, 2021 and validated by field interviews

correspondence, communications and data

imperfections

Turkmenistan,TKM,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The legal framework for data protection in Turkmenistan appears progressive, establishing a consent-based regime, and hence, partly reflecting the rules and principles outlined in the GDPR. It does have certain positive features, such as obligations imposed on the data holders concerning data security, its depersonalization in certain circumstances, and its destruction upon request of the data subject (1). Nonetheless, the framework implements the simplified approach suggested by the GDPR (2) and has noticeable gaps. The Law, for instance, does not require registration of a personal data database and notification of data subject to the data breach and does not envisage the appointment of a data protection officer. The framework also vaguely defines the exceptional cases when the consent of data subjects can be overridden in the name of protecting national security and constitutional rights and freedoms of the data subjects and other individuals, laying the groundwork for the potential abuse of office by security services and other state institutions. The protection of personal data is undermined further by the poor enforcement and lack of independent institutions safeguarding citizens from arbitrary and disproportionate interference (3), which is reflected in the country's poor human rights record (4).
Sources
(1) Law of Turkmenistan No.519-V 'On Information about Private Life and its Protection,' 2017, http://www.worldlii.org/int/other/NDPrivLegis/2017/13.html
(2) DLA Piper, Data Protection Laws of the World: Turkmenistan, n.d., https://www.dlapiperdataprotection.com/index.html?t=law&c=TM
(3) Bertelsmann Stiftung Transformation Index, BTI 2020 Turkmenistan Country Report, https://www.bti-project.org/en/reports/country-report-TKM-2020.html

(4) 2020 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Turkmenistan, US Department of State, https://www.state.gov/reports/2020-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/turkmenistan/",2.0,1.0,1.0,48.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,IDFI Georgia,Central Asia,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Ashgabat,Ashgabat,37.9375,58.38,TM,primary,Gobernanza

Uganda,UGA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The government of Uganda has enacted laws, and regulations that provide a comprehensive framework for the protection of personal data. The Constitution of Uganda 1995, Article 27, Section 2 provides the grounding for the protection of personal data by prohibiting interference with the privacy of a person's home, correspondence, communication or other property (1). This provision was operationalized by The Data Protection and Privacy Act passed in February of 2019 and which provides a comprehensive framework for the protection of the individual the privacy and of personal data (2). This was followed by the development of the Data Protection and Privacy Regulations and approved in 2021 (3). There are cases of the Government of Uganda enforcing these legal frameworks. For example, Unwanted Witness petitioned the Speaker of Parliament against the SafeBoda app highlighting their failures to comply with data protection law that lead to the National Information Technology Authority Uganda (NITA-U) taking enforcement action of requesting the entity to make fundamental changes to how they handle people's personal data in particular in their information notices and data sharing practices (4). There are reports on how COVID-19 surveillance in Uganda is reducing people's data protection rights. For example, the Guidelines on COVID-19 Self Quarantine require individuals to provide their name, next of kin, physical address and telephone contact and permit the government surveillance teams to monitor individuals for 14 days (5). The Data Protection and Privacy Act 2019 is silent about budget allocations for implementation of this legal framework but it is important to note that it falls within the mandate of NITA-U. Lastly, the government of Uganda recently appointed the National Director of Personal Data Protection Office, an independent office under the National Information Technology Authority-Uganda (NITA-U)(6).
Sources:

Ukraine,UKR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The primary Personal Data Protection law was adopted in 2010 in Ukraine (1) based on old European Directives and practices (2). This legislation provides a framework for personal data subjects' rights and data holder obligations; it applies across the country and all sectors. The Parliament Commissionaire on Human Rights is responsible for personal data protection oversight, and people can apply to the Commissionaire to protect their rights (3). The Commissionaire on Human Rights developed regulations about personal data processing, sensitive data (4). However, the framework doesn't provide substantial protection of location-related data or protection and awareness of algorithmic decision-making (5). The framework is outdated and needs to be harmonized with the GDPR (6). This is why the new law draft based on discussions and GDPR rules was registered in the parliament in June 2021 (7).
Source (Links accessed 1-27 July 2021)
(1) The Personal Data Protection Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2297-17
(2) Interview with Vlad Nekrutenko, co-founder of PrivacyHub, GDPR expert
(3) The Personal Data Protection Law, Article 22: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2297-17

(4) Typical procedure for processing personal data developed by the Parliament Commissionaire on Human Rights: http://zakon5.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/v1_02715-14?test=n6HMfJRw7UpVmUn6ZilPzapnHI41gs80msh8Ie6#n11

(5) Procedure for notifying the Parliament Commissioner for Human Rights about the processing of personal data, which poses a special risk to the rights and freedoms of personal data subjects, about the structural unit or responsible person organizing work related to personal data protection during their processing, as well as the disclosure of such information: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/v1_02715-14/print1443613185179245#n215
(6) Interview with Vlad Nekrutenko, co-founder of PrivacyHub, GDPR expert

(7) New draft of the law on personal data protection was registered in June 2021, discussed in 2019-2020: https://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/zweb2/webproc4_1?pf3511=72160 based on GDPR",2.0,1.0,1.0,64.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,IDFI Georgia,Eastern Europe,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Kyiv,Kyiv,50.45,30.5233,UA,primary,Gobernanza

United Arab Emirates,ARE,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"UAE Constitution gives citizens a general right to privacy, and provisions of the Federal Law No. 5 of 1985: The Civil Code as amended by Federal Law No. 1 of 1987 (1) and the Federal Law No. 3 of 1987: The Penal Code (2) are also relevant when considering privacy related issues. Otherwise there is no legal framework for protection of personal data.
Dubai International Finance Center (DIFC) have its own data protection law since July 2020 (3).

3- https://www.difc.ae/application/files/6115/9358/6486/Data_Protection_Law_DIFC_Law_No.5_of_2020.pdf/",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Birzeit University,Western Asia,Middle East and North Africa,Dubai,Dubai,25.2631,55.2972,AE,admin,Gobernanza

United Kingdom,GBR,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The UK inherited the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) as a former EU member state but this is modified - primarily to remove any reference to the EU and other details - into the ""UK GDPR"".[1] The substantive provisions are the same and this is a comprehensive framework.

The UK GDPR is complemented by the Data Protection Act (DPA) 2018,[2] which provides particular details relevant to the UK. Every EU country required a complementary law to GDPR. The UK incorporates the EU Directive for data protection in law enforcement[3] and extends some provisions to intelligence agencies. The DPA 2018 also amends dozens of UK laws and regulations to bring them up to date.

The Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2003[4] cover several areas including: communications such as calls and texts but not online services like Skype or Zoom, electronic marketing and spam, and online tracking and cookies.
These Regulations transpose the EU E-Privacy Directive Directive 2002/58/EC (amended) but the EU is currently drafting a replacement instrument and the UK will soon have a different regime.
https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/eprivacy-regulation

The UK government's National Data Strategy[5] declares the intention to create a ""pro-growth and trusted"" data regime in the UK, which has raised concerns that it may steer away form the current high protections.

The close relationship between the UK intelligence agencies and their US counterparts has caused anxiety in Europe, leading the European Parliament to pass a resolution[6] demanding that the EU does not allow unfettered personal data transfers after Brexit without extra guarantees. The European Commission ignored the resolution and agreed to give the UK an ""adequacy decision"" that enables cross border data flows more or less as if the UK was still in the EU.[7]
[1] UK GDPR Keeling Schedule, 2018. https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/685632/2018-03-05_Keeling_Schedule.pdf
[2] Data Protection Act (DPA), 2018. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2018/12/contents
[3] Part 3, Data Protection Act,  2018.  https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2018/12/part/3
[4] Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations, 2003. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2003/2426/contents

[5] Response to consultation on the National Data Strategy, 2020. https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/uk-national-data-strategy-nds-consultation/outcome/government-response-to-the-consultation-on-the-national-data-strategy

[6] Data protection: MEPs urge the Commission to amend UK adequacy decisions, 2021. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20210517IPR04124/data-protection-meps-urge-the-commission-to-amend-uk-adequacy-decisions

[7] Data protection: Commission adopts adequacy decisions for the UK, 2021. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_21_3183",2.0,1.0,1.0,77.0,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Access Info Europe,Northern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",London,London,51.5072,-0.1275,GB,primary,Gobernanza

United States,USA,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. § 552a, outlines a broad framework for privacy for Federal datasets only. (1) The Privacy Act prohibits the disclosure of a record about an individual from a system of records absent the written consent of the individual, unless the disclosure is pursuant to one of twelve statutory exceptions. The Act also provides individuals with a means by which to seek access to and amendment of their records, and sets forth various agency record-keeping requirements. In addition to the Privacy Act, there is a range of data protection regulations for specific datasets collected by the Federal Government which can be observed in the Federal Privacy Council's Law Library. (2) For example, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) regulates personal health information and sets limits and conditions on the uses and disclosures. In reaction to the COVID-19 Pandemic, the Federal Government waived all provisions of the HIPAA privacy, security, and breach notification rules if a telehealth provider acted in good faith compliance with the guidance. Lastly, there is a range of state data protection regulations covering consumer data, biometrics, and more. (3) (4) (5)
Sources:
1. Department of Justice Privacy Act of 1974 Overview, https://www.justice.gov/opcl/overview-privacy-act-1974-2020-edition
2. Federal Privacy Council Law Library, https://www.fpc.gov/law-library/
3. U.S. Biometric Laws & Pending Legislation Tracker, 2021, https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/u-s-biometric-laws-pending-legislation-5729436/
4. US State Privacy Legislation Tracker, 2022, https://iapp.org/resources/article/us-state-privacy-legislation-tracker/

5. Key HIPAA Changes in Light of COVID-19, 2020, https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/key-hipaa-changes-in-light-of-covid-19-26761/",2.0,1.0,1.0,45.9,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,0.0,50948.0,0.1,0.03,0.2,Access Info Europe,Northern America,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",New York,New York,40.6943,-73.9249,US,admin,Gobernanza

Uruguay,URY,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"Since 2008, Uruguay has a broad and comprehensive legal framework that guarantees the protection of personal data. This is stated in the Law 18.331 and its regulatory Decrete 414/009 (1,2). Further, Law 19.670 (articles 37 to 40) -and Decrete 64/2020- widen the scope of application of the Law 18.331 to international data holders and establishes new obligations for data holders in general (3,4).

Uzbekistan,UZB,Governance,GOVERNANCE,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,Governance (G): Data protection,Primary,G.GOVERNANCE.DPL,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data?",1,response,"The legislative history of data protection in Uzbekistan can be divided into two periods. The first period started with the Law of Uzbekistan of 24 April 1994 No 400-I on Guarantees and Freedom of Access to Information (only available in Uzbek and Russian) ('the Law on Information')[1], and lasted for 16 years, until the enactment of Law of Uzbekistan of 2 July 2019 No. ЗРУ-547 on Personal Data (available in Uzbek, Russian and English)[2] (The Law on Personal Data), which initiated the second period.

In terms of the Law of Personal Data, it applies to relations arising from the processing and protection of personal data (Article 3 of the Law on Personal Data). The participants in the processing of personal data include the operator of a database and the owner of a database, as well as any representatives or third parties (Article 9 of the Law on Personal Data). An owner and/or operator may be a State body, an individual, or a legal entity (Article 4 of the Law on Personal Data).
The Law on Personal Data does not explicitly define its territorial scope.

The main regulators are the Cabinet of Ministers and the State Personalisation Center ('the SPC') under the Cabinet of Ministers. Several other functions in the sphere of information (data) protection are carried out by the following State bodies:

column2: the Ministry for Development of Information Technologies and Communications of the Republic of Uzbekistan ('MITC');
the Central Bank of the Republic of Uzbekistan ('the Central Bank');
the State Inspection for Control in the Field of Information and Telecommunications of the Republic of Uzbekistan;
the Information Agency and the Information Center; and
the Interagency Coordination Commission for the improvement of the effectiveness of information activities and data transfer.

column1: The Law on Personal Data does not include any provision that controllers/operators should carry out Data Protection Impact Assessments.
There are no data breach notification requirements under the Law on Personal Data.
The Law on Personal Data does not specifically regulate contractual relations between the owner and the operator.

Notably, data subjects have a statutory duty to provide their personal data in order to protect the foundations of the constitutional order, and for reasons related to morality, health, rights, and the legitimate interests of citizens of Uzbekistan, ensure State defense and security. The subject of personal data has the right to appeal to the authorized state body or court on the protection of his rights and legitimate interests in relation to personal data(Article 30 of the Law on Personal Data).

Persons guilty of violating the legislation on personal data shall be liable in accordance with the established procedure(See: Article 46 of the Code of Administrative Responsibility of the Republic of Uzbekistan[3], Article 141 of the Criminal Code[4]).
Enforcement decisions. No decisions have been rendered yet.
Sources:

Angola,AGO,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Law No 7/04 of 17 June 2004 is fundamental to understanding the electoral process in Angola.

In its article 94, the law states that the election campaign can be funded by: a) State contributions; b) contributions from the candidates themselves and from the political parties; c) donations from national individuals or corporate bodies resident or headquartered in the country e) contributions from Angolan citizens' national non-governmental organizations, under the terms to be regulated by the National Electoral Commission, or f) contributions from homologous parties, under the terms to be regulated by the National Electoral Commission.

In article 96, the same law states that candidates for elections must account for all income and expenses incurred in the election campaign within thirty days of the official proclamation of the results of the poll, indicating precisely the origin of the income and the destination of the expenses.

However, these provisions on electoral transparency are not respected by the different political parties. Since the creation of the law, the expenses and revenues of each political party are not known.
Sources:
(1) https://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/africa/AO/Lei%20No%207%2004%20de%2017%20de%20Junho.pdf

Argentina,ARG,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Laws and other regulations establish strong obligations to collect and publish data.

The Law of Political Financing in Argentina requires political parties to inform about the origin and destination of the funds received. This is so both for the ordinary life of the Political Party and for the electoral campaign. The law establishes the presentation of financial statements and campaign reports. It also establishes the publication of these reports in order to make them available to the public.

Armenia,ARM,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Parties, adopted in 2016, requires the parties to submit their financial and accounting reports. The reports specifying sources of the financial means, spending as well as property, should be published on mass media and then presented to the Central Electoral Commission.

Government Decree N-403-N of April 20th, 2017 defines the procedure for publishing and submitting the report by parties on financial means, spending, and property, and provides the respective templates (2).
Sources
(1): The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Parties, 2016; https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=110534

(2): Government Decree N-403-N of April 20th, 2017; https://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?docID=112900",2.0,1.0,1.0,82.365,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,IDFI Georgia,Western Asia,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Yerevan,Yerevan,40.1814,44.5144,AM,primary,Integridad Política

Australia,AUS,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Political Parties must self-report annually and after an election using the transparency register, Section 287N: Transparency Register, Commonwealth Electoral Act, 1918.

A report into political finance in Australia found that the disclosure scheme is inadequate in that parties are not required to categorise receipts, meaning breaking down the types of donations and their source is very labour intensive and that the nature of self-reporting leaves the scheme open to rife under-reporting. pg 15. (1) The author of the report claims the disclosure scheme is almost designed to be ineffectual and lacks the ""teeth"" to kerb impropriety, while disclosures may raise suspicion - the lax reporting requirements mean only casual links are establishable in lieu of a full police investigation. pg24 (ibid, 1).
The report also indicates that political parties are flouting their obligations under the scheme with little consequence. pg. 18. (ibid, 1)
The Guardian reported that ""Federally, the public is forced to wait more than a year in some cases to find out who has bankrolled the various parties.
The delay often robs voters of the information prior to casting their votes. Donations made in the lead-up to the May 2019 election, for example, were not disclosed until February 2020.""2
Sources:

1. Young, Sally and Tham, Joo Cheong. Political finance in Australia: A skewed and secret system. School of Social Sciences The Australian National University, report no 7, 2006. https://apo.org.au/sites/default/files/resource-files/2006-11/apo-nid3933.pdf

2. Knaus, Christopher. September 2020. AEC not punishing political donors that break the rules, damning audit finds, https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/sep/17/australian-electoral-commission-not-punishing-political-donors-that-break-the-rules-damning-audit-finds.

Australian Government, Attorney-General's Department. Transparency Register, https://transparency.ag.gov.au/",2.0,1.0,1.0,70.395,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Australia and New Zealand,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Melbourne,Melbourne,-37.8142,144.9631,AU,admin,Integridad Política

Azerbaijan,AZE,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Law on political parties, which is the primary regulatory framework, demands that Political parties should publish their annual financial statements in the media together with the auditor's report (Article 21.5) (03.06. 1992 № 147) (1). The law discusses ""information"" disclosure, there is no obligation for the parties to open information as open data. All published information is in PDF format (scanned image).
Annual financial reports of political parties are posted on the official website of the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Azerbaijan (2) (Article 21.6) (03.06. 1992 № 147).
According to the Law on political parties, the maximum amount of donations a person can make to one or more parties during the year may not exceed ten thousand manats (Article 19.7).

In conclusion, the regulations and legal framework give a sufficient overview of political party accountability in terms of financial activities. Nevertheless, in practice, such accountability is formal and does not cover the details of financial resource usage. We can see it from the published reports. For example, the leading party, The New Azerbaijan Party, published one page PDF financial report (4). The Party presents the costs with general statements like ""funds spent on current works"". Such descriptions do not allow a citizen to understand precisely what was the current works. This is applicable for other reports as well.
Source
