column1: Bahamas, The,BHS,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The existing act governing parliamentary elections does not address campaign finances (1). The Act and IDEA assessment (2) is presented as evidence. The Integrity Commission Bill addresses some gaps in public access to information to campaign funding of political parties but it yet to be debated as evidenced by the Eyewitness News report (3).
(1) Parliamentary Election Act, 1992. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/1992/1992-0001/ParliamentaryElectionsAct_1.pdf
(2) IDEA - Bahamas, 2017. https://www.idea.int/data-tools/country-view/69/55

(3) Campaign finance a necessity as we enter 'silly season', says ORG, 2020. https://ewnews.com/campaign-finance-a-necessity-as-we-enter-silly-season-says-org",1.0,0.5,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,The Caribbean Open Institute (COI),Caribbean,Latin America and the Caribbean,Nassau,Nassau,25.0781,-77.3386,BS,primary,Integridad Política

Bahrain,BHR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Bahrain held the first legislative elections in 2002 to elect a forty-seat four years parliament (1). Elections in Bahrain is subject to the Law No. 14 of 2002 exercising political rights, Decree-Law No. 15 of 2002 regarding the Shura and Representatives Councils, and the Decree-Law No. 71 of 2014 regarding defining electoral districts and districts, their boundaries and sub-committees for Parliament elections (2).

However the research did not find any relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance in Bahrain. However there is only one line in the Candidate election guide mentioning that ""The candidate is prohibited from receiving any money for electoral propaganda from any party"".
## References
1- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Bahraini_general_election
2- https://www.vote.bh/Media/publications/Group.pdf

3- https://www.vote.bh/Media/publications/Candidate.pdf",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Birzeit University,Western Asia,Middle East and North Africa,Manama,Manama,26.225,50.5775,BH,primary,Integridad Política

Bangladesh,BGD,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Representation of the People Order, 1972 (President's Order) requires political parties in Bangladesh to submit an expenditure statement within 90 days of the completion of election.
The law offers scope to inspect the data, in the format as submitted by political parties, on payment. Quote from the law

44D.(1) The statement, return and documents submitted under Articles 44AA, 44C and 44CCC shall be kept by the Returning Officer or the Commission, as the case may be, in his or its office or at such other convenient place as he or it may think fit and shall, during one year from the date of receipt, be open for inspection by any person on payment of the prescribed fees.""

All the electoral candidates in Bangladesh ought to submit an affidavit along with election campaign finance and income tax statement to the election commission which has to be made public by the commission pursuant to a 2005 High Court verdict. According to the verdict the commission is bound to publish 8 types of information about electoral candidates on its website. Since 2008, the commission has been publishing the information, but they are publishing the hand written PDF files submitted by the candidates.
In the affidavit, submitted to the election commission, there are sections where the candidate has to list sources of campaign finance.
Sources:
(1)  The Representation of the People Order, 1972 (President's Order) (http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/act-details-424.html)

(2) Candidates Affidavit (in Bangla) (http://202.40.184.221/asset2013/index2018.php)",2.0,1.0,1.0,15.45,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,East-West Management Institute Inc. (EWMI),Southern Asia,South and East Asia,Dhaka,Dhaka,23.7639,90.3889,BD,primary,Integridad Política

Belarus,BLR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Law About political parties (1) Article 24. mentions various restrictions on the financing of political parties and unions, however, there is no mention of publicizing or collecting this data in any form. But since there is a government agency in charge of monitoring the adherence to these restrictions and since political parties are mandated to send reports of their financial activities (and other activities), it can be assumed that this data is collected and archived in some form.
Sources:

(1):https://pravo.by/document/?guid=3871&p0=V19403266",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,IDFI Georgia,Eastern Europe,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Minsk,Minsk,53.9,27.5667,BY,primary,Integridad Política

Belize,BLZ,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"There simply are no campaign finance regulations in Belize. Some elements in Belizean society are calling for change in this status quo (1).
Source

(1) News article calling for campaign finance legislation, 2020. https://www.breakingbelizenews.com/2020/02/13/belize-network-of-ngos-calls-on-government-to-take-steps-to-introduce-campaign-finance-legislation/",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,The Caribbean Open Institute (COI),Central America,Latin America and the Caribbean,Belize City,Belize City,17.4986,-88.1886,BZ,admin,Integridad Política

Benin,BEN,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Decree (1) for financing the political parties for the year 2020 was issued in Benin. It is made in application of Law (2) on the financing of political parties in the Republic of Benin. This provision made it possible to allocate three billion to the three (3) political parties eligible for public funding after the 2020 elections, for the year 2021. But before, each party sought funds to finance its activities. So far, the practice of public funding has not yet been well tested. Supporting documents for expenditure are provided to the competent authorities. No information filters on the use made of resources let alone the evidence of uses. Data on party funding is not available online, and the law and regulations do not provide for the release of the data. The political parties produce the receipts of expenses and submit them to whom it may concern. There is no public accountability for the use of political party funding.
Sources:
(1) http://levenementprecis.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/D%C3%A9cret-2020-362-portant-financement-des-partis-politiques.pdf
(2) https://documentation-anbenin.org/s/textes-de-lois/item/2060

(3) https://archives.beninwebtv.com/2020/09/benin-liste-des-partis-politiques-eligibles-au-financement-de-letat-en-2020/",2.0,1.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Western Africa,Africa,Cotonou,Cotonou,6.3667,2.4333,BJ,primary,Integridad Política

Bolivia,BOL,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,In Bolivia there is no regulation that establishes the collection and publication of data on the financing of campaigns and political parties.,0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,ILDA,South America,Latin America and the Caribbean,Santa Cruz de la Sierra,Santa Cruz de la Sierra,-17.7892,-63.1975,BO,primary,Integridad Política

Botswana,BWA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"There is currently no relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance that provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on the campaign and party finance in Botswana

The idea of establishing a guideline has been raised for some time and IEC Botswana has considered this issue amongst the various political parties for discussion, but consensus on the final form of Code has not yet been established.",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Southern Africa,Africa,Gaborone,Gaborone,-24.6581,25.9122,BW,primary,Integridad Política

Brazil,BRA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Electoral Court is composed of the Superior Electoral Court, Regional Courts, Judges and Electoral Boards.
The Electoral Court is responsible for organizing all stages of the Brazilian electoral process, from electoral registration to the diplomacy of elected candidates.
The Electoral Justice Portal provides data for consultation of candidates, electorate, election results and information about campaigns, but statistical data are available in xls or zip tables (1).

There are open data on the Brazilian Open Data Portal (2), but the data is out of date. All data from 2022 from the Electoral Data Repository environment will be replaced by the TSE Open Data Portal. There are already data available at https://dadosabertos.tse.jus.br/. Election statistics available on a panel (3), but no download option.

In February 2021, Ordinance No. 93 (4) provides for the Open Data Policy of the Superior Electoral Court and other measures. Despite the recently approved Open Data Policy (5), the electoral data repository makes the data available in zip., Xml and csv.
Source:
(1) http://www.justicaeleitoral.jus.br/eleicoes/estatisticas/index.html
(2) https://dados.gov.br/dataset?tags=TSE
(3) https://www.tse.jus.br/eleicoes/estatisticas/estatisticas-eleitorais
(4) https://www.tse.jus.br/legislacao/compilada/prt/2021/portaria-no-93-de-12-de-fevereiro-de-2021?SearchableText=dados%20abertos

(5) https://www.tse.jus.br/eleicoes/estatisticas/repositorio-de-dados-eleitorais-1/repositorio-de-dados-eleitorais",2.0,1.0,1.0,21.96,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,ILDA,South America,Latin America and the Caribbean,São Paulo,Sao Paulo,-23.55,-46.6333,BR,admin,Integridad Política

Bulgaria,BGR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Political parties have to draw up a financial statement on the preceding calendar year, including information on the headquarters and the regional chapters, under art. 34 of the Political Parties Act (PPA) (2005) (1). This report is published in a public register by the Bulgarian National Audit Office (art. 34, par. 6 of the PPA).(2) Also, the audit reports of political parties' financial statements are published in the same register (art. 35a, par. 4 of the PPA). The parties, coalitions, and initiative committees participating in election campaigns have to file with the Bulgarian National Audit Office the financial statements of income, expenditures and payment commitments in connection with the election campaign, accompanied by a statement from their bank account, up to 30 days after the election, under art. 172 of the Electoral Code.(3) These financial statements are published by the Audit Office in the unified public register under art. 171 of the Electoral Code.(4) Art. 34, 35, and 35a of the PPA and art. 171, and  172 of the Electoral Code provide for a control of the financial statements by the Audit Office and in some cases by the National Revenue Agency (the tax authority).
(1) Закон за политическите партии (Political Parties Act) (PPA).2005. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/en/laws/ldoc/2135501352
(2) Отчети на партии (Parties reports). Bulgarian National Audit Office. https://www.bulnao.government.bg/bg/kontrol-partii/otcheti-na-partii/
(3) Изборен кодекс (Electoral Code). 2014. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2136112596

(4) Единен Регистър по Изборния Кодекс (Unified Register under the Electoral Code). Bulgarian National Audit Office. https://erik.bulnao.government.bg/RegDonors/Default.aspx",2.0,1.0,1.0,79.23,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Eastern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Sofia,Sofia,42.7,23.33,BG,primary,Integridad Política

Burkina Faso,BFA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"There are laws that provide a basis for campaign and party finance but not for the collection and publication of campaign and party finance data.

There is Law No. 008-2009/an on the financing of political parties and organizations and election campaigns. Under this law, the State contributes to the financing of the costs of the electoral campaigns of political parties and organizations through public funds and this applies to municipal, legislative and presidential elections (1).

There is also Law No. 012-2000/AN of May 2, 2000 on the financing of political party activities and election campaigns, amended by Law 012-2001/AN of June 28, 2001, which is a very partial regulation of political financing in Burkina Faso (2).

According to the texts issued by the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI), Article 5 stipulates that: Any party or grouping of political parties whose lists do not respect the provisions of this law loses 50% of public funding for election campaigns. And Article 6 mentions that: Any political party or grouping of political parties that has reached or exceeded the result of 30% of elected officials of either sex, benefits from additional public financing on condition that it has respected the provisions of Article 3 above. The amount of this additional public financing is equal to the amount received by the political party or grouping of parties for the financing of the electoral campaign (3).
Sources :
(1)https://www.assembleenationale.bf/spip.php?article15
(2)https://cdn.accf-francophonie.org/2019/03/Bulletin6-TI-Ch2.4-BurkinaFaso.pdf

(3)http://www.ceni.bf/sites/default/files/CODE%20ELECTORAL%202020%20%20DEFINITIF_OK.pdf",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Western Africa,Africa,Ouagadougou,Ouagadougou,12.3686,-1.5275,BF,primary,Integridad Política

Cambodia,KHM,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Cambodia's 1997 Law on Political Parties requires every party to submit a yearly financial report to the Ministry of Economy and Finance that must include the party's bank statements, lists of expenditures, and a narrative report of the party's principal activities. Although parties are required to submit a record of expenditures, they are not required to publicly declare party assets. The MEF is responsible for reviewing these reports to ensure that there is no conflict with the constitution. There are no provisions concerning public disclosure of the review findings. The draft Access to Information Law does not cover political finance either. In other words, there is no framework in Cambodia for the collection and publication of data on political campaigns and party finance.
Sources:
(1) Cambodia's 1997 Law on Political Parties. https://www.refworld.org/docid/3ae6b51414.html

(2) Cambodia's draft Access to Information Law.",0.0,0.0,1.0,0.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,East-West Management Institute Inc. (EWMI),South-Eastern Asia,South and East Asia,Phnom Penh,Phnom Penh,11.5694,104.9211,KH,primary,Integridad Política

Cameroon,CMR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"There is a framework that is defined by the law N° 2012/1 of 19 April 2012 relating to the electoral code, supplemented by Law N° 2019/005 of 25 April 2019. Yet, the Constitution provides a general framework for the exercise of elections but the technical framework remains devolved to the Electoral Code. There is no specific mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.

Colombia,COL,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Statutory Law 1475 of 2011 (1) regulates the functioning and organization of political parties and movements, electoral processes, and adds other provisions. This law sets out the principles and operating rules for participation mechanisms, the sanctioning regime for movements and parties, forms of action in the event of dissolutions, forms of financing and accountability, organization of electoral campaigns and other provisions for electoral days and new implementations.

The data portal Clear Accounts (2) in Elections attached to the National Electoral Council contains the data of the latest electoral processes regarding candidates, elections and political parties. Additionally, data sets related to previous electoral processes at the territorial and national level are available.
##Sources:
(1) https://www.funcionpublica.gov.co/eva/gestornormativo/norma.php?i=43332

(2) https://cnecuentasclaras.gov.co/",2.0,1.0,1.0,46.6925,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,ILDA,South America,Latin America and the Caribbean,Bogotá,Bogota,4.7111,-74.0722,CO,primary,Integridad Política

Costa Rica,CRI,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Regulation on the Financing of Political Parties of the Supreme Court of Elections, the electoral ruling institution, oversees all issued related to the collection and publication of data on campaign and party finance.

http://www.pgrweb.go.cr/scij/Busqueda/Normativa/Normas/nrm_texto_completo.aspx?nValor1=1&nValor2=66556",2.0,1.0,1.0,75.24,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,ILDA,Central America,Latin America and the Caribbean,San José,San Jose,9.9325,-84.08,CR,primary,Integridad Política

Croatia,HRV,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Act on financing political activities, election campaigns, and referendums (1) bind political parties and candidates to upload all the data on the campaign and party finance through the funding monitoring information system. Also, the State Electoral Commission of the Republic of Croatia is obligated to publish this data using the same information system and monitor published reports. (2)

The same Act defines election campaigns while third-party campaigning is vaguely mentioned only in the cases of violation of election silence, leaving unregulated space for election interference by interested parties. (3)
The donation report should contain the specified data on the donor for the campaign and party finance. (4)

Political parties and independent MPs are obligated to submit annual financial reports with information on the condition and structure and changes in the value and volume of assets, liabilities, own resources, income, and expenses. (5) Besides the annual financial statements, there are prescribed deadlines for financial reports for election campaigns and semi-annual reports on donations for political activities. (6)
State Audit Office audits while the banks are obliged to submit all required data on transactions on accounts at the written request of the State Election Commission. (7)
Sources:
(1) The Act on financing political activities, election campaigns, and referendums, 2019/20, http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_29_602.html
(2) The funding monitoring information system (regular financing) https://www.izbori.hr/arhiva-izbora/index.html#/app/financiranje; (election financing) https://www.izbori.hr/lokalni2021/financ/1/

(3) The Act on financing political activities, election campaigns, and referendums, article 2, paragraph 4, 2019/20, http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_29_602.html

(4) The Act on financing political activities, election campaigns, and referendums, article 21, paragraph 2 and article 39, paragraph 2, 2019/20,  http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_29_602.html

(5) The Act on Financial Operations and Accounting of Non-Profit Organizations, article 29, paragraph 1, https://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/125068/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2014_10_121_2300.html

(6) The Act on financing political activities, election campaigns, and referendums, article 48, paragraph 2 and article 49, paragraph 2, 2019/20, http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_29_602.html

(7) The Act on financing political activities, election campaigns, and referendums, article 48, paragraph 2 and article 49, paragraph 2, 2019/20, http://digarhiv.gov.hr/arhiva/263/195825/narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/full/2019_03_29_602.html",2.0,1.0,1.0,79.1825,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Southern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Zagreb,Zagreb,45.8131,15.9775,HR,primary,Integridad Política

Czechia,CZE,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The topic is generally regulated by Legislative Act on Association in Political Parties and Political Movements (1)
It is supervised by Office for Supervision over the Management of Political Parties and Movements (2)
The details are provided opinion of the Office or/and in special website of the Office's vice chairman (3)
Information on political finances are provided in more user friendly way by an independent project run by a NGO (4)
campaign finance is governed by Acts, which govern various types of elections, e.g. the parliamentary one (5)
1) Act on Association in Political Parties and Political Movements, https://www.zakonyprolidi.cz/cs/1991-424
2) Office for Supervision over the Management of Political Parties and movements, https://www.udhpsh.cz/
3) Independent website run by the Vice Chairman of the Office for Supervision over the Management of Political Parties and movements, https://outly.cz/?page_id=1803
4) Independent project showing political finances, https://www.politickefinance.cz/

Finland,FIN,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Only candidates elected are required to disclose information on their election funding. (1) The funding to be disclosed is defined in the law as ""the funding raised to cover the costs of the candidate's election campaign incurred over a period starting no earlier than six months before the election day and ending no later than two weeks after the election day irrespective of when such costs are paid."" (2) Similarly to a candidate, a political party must disclose the funds raised and spent during a campaign. (3)

While the candidate is not obligated to report their personal income or assets in the election funding disclosure, information on their taxable income is separately available based on their tax assessment. (4)
(1): Act on a Candidate's Election Funding 273/2009 Section 5(1)
(2): Act on a Candidate's Election Funding 273/2009 Section 2
(3): Act on Political Parties 10/1969 Section 9 b (amendment 16.7.2010/683), https://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/ajantasa/1969/19690010#P9b

(4): Act on the public disclosure and confidentiality of tax information 1346/1999 Section 5",2.0,1.0,1.0,60.94249999999999,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Northern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Helsinki,Helsinki,60.1708,24.9375,FI,primary,Integridad Política

France,FRA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"France has a relatively robust legal framework on political finance, with clear definitions of campaigning activities, clear rules on income and spendings allowed, and spending limits during campaigns. Those rules are mostly incorporated in the Electoral Code for campaign finance and in the Law n°88-227 of March 11 1988 (1), which is regularly updated (last substantial reform in september 2017). This is complemented by official guidelines published by the National Commission for Campaign Finance and Political Finance (CNCCFP) summarizing hard law and case law (2). Candidates and parties must comply with the same accounting guidelines, set by a National Accounting Authority (3). According to the Code Electoral, « the commission ensures the publication of campaign finance accounts in an open standard, easily reusable and machine-readable, and ensures their publication in the Official Journal. » (4)

In general, rules are stronger for campaign finance (all invoices must be reported to the CNCCFP, etc.) than for party finance (data only reported as summary) ; this can be explained by article 4 of the Constitution, which states that political parties ""carry out their activities freely"" (5).

Despite this relatively strong processes on the paper, major scandals have occurred in the last decades, notably about the presidential elections (6) and illicit loans from foreign organisations (7). Therefore, civil society is actively calling for reforms to address loopholes (8).
In many cases, it is necessary to make a physical appointment and go on site to get access to some data, notably for supporting documents that are never available online.
(1) Code Electoral https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/codes/id/LEGITEXT000006070239/
Law n°88-227 of 11 March 1988 on political finance transparency https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/loda/id/JORFTEXT000000321646/2021-10-06/
(2) CNCCFP. 2021. ""Guide du candidat et du mandataire"". CNCCFP. http://www.cnccfp.fr/docs/campagne/cnccfp_2021_guide_candidat_et_mandataire.pdf
(3) National Accounting Authority. Rule n° 2018-03. October 12, 2018.
https://www.anc.gouv.fr/files/live/sites/anc/files/contributed/ANC/1_Normes_françaises/Reglements/2018/Reglt_2018_03/Reglt2018-03_partis_politiques.pdf
(4) Electoral Code, First book, First title, Chapter V bis, article L 52-12 https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/codes/article_lc/LEGIARTI000039446161/
(5) French Constitution, Article 4, 1958. https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/loda/article_lc/LEGIARTI000019240999/

(6) The Guardian via Reuters. Nicolas Sarkozy under investigation over 2012 campaign funds. 16 February 2016. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/16/nicolas-sarkozy-under-investigation-over-2012-campaign-funds
(7) Gatehouse, Gabriel. BBC. ""Marine Le Pen: Who's funding France's far right?"", 3 April 2017. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39478066

(8) Foucraut, Elsa. 2019. Financement de la vie politique : l'urgence d'une réforme. Ghana,GHA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Political Parties Law Act 574, (2000) is a law that regulates the activities of political parties in Ghana. This law gives guidelines on how political parties can be founded, registered, and operated in Ghana.  It clearly outlines the operations of political parties, funding of political parties, and other general and miscellaneous provisions.

This Act requires collecting specific information on income, spending, assets and liabilities of political parties. The Political Parties Act, 2000 mandates political parties to submit financial reports with the source of its funds. This must be done within six months from 31st December of each year, file with the Electoral Commission  of Ghana.

Guyana,GUY,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In Guyana, there are campaign finance laws, however, political parties are not required to disclose where their money comes from to run their campaigns.

Sources (1)https://www.stabroeknews.com/2020/01/05/sunday/conversation-tree/campaign-finance-reform/;https://www.stabroeknews.com/2019/12/08/news/guyana/jagdeo-promises-campaign-finance-reform-as-need-for-transparency-seen-amidst-challenges/https://gecom.org.gy/home/.

Guyana's legal framework lacks legislation on party and campaign finance beyond ceilings for election expenditure and a simple requirement that declarations of electoral expenses must be submitted to GECOM after the election. The absence of campaign-finance law
allows for great inequalities between political parties, as well as a lack of transparency about the
sources and uses of campaign funding.

Honduras,HND,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The law (1) applies to those who participate in the elections of the central government, municipal and deputies. The parameters to be followed with the accountability of those who participate in popular elections are well defined. In addition to the regulations, there is also the Honduras Accountability Platform (2) is an initiative that seeks to promote transparency regarding the financing of electoral campaigns, as well as help Obliged Subjects to make their income declarations and expenses, this platform is sponsored by UNDP.

Despite the approval of a new legal framework and a Clean Policy Unit, efforts to regulate the contributions received by political parties come up against restrictions that prevent knowing who the private contributors are and taking actions in the interests of transparency and accountability. accounts.

Hong Kong,HKG,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In Hong Kong, the Elections Corrupt and Illegal Conduct Ordinance (1) requires the election candidates to report the donations they received and their expenses to the authorities but there is no requirement to publish such information. Other than this, there is no regulation on publishing the state of finance of political parties.

Paragraph 16.33 of the Guidelines on Election-related Activities (2) states, ""A candidate should submit invoices and receipts with the following particulars, including: (a) date; (b) details of the expenditure item (i.e. information and amount of the goods or services); (c) information of the organisation or person (other than the candidate himself/herself) providing the goods or services; and (d) the information supporting that the organisation or person (other than the candidate himself/herself) providing the goods or services has received the relevant payment in full (e.g. name and signature of the recipient, or the stamp of the organisation or signature of its authorised person).""
Sources:

party financial management, 2009 which the reporting and collection of information is regulated by them. Italy,ITA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Italy is a particular country in Europe as to political financing, since it has gradually abolished (since 2014) (1) public financing for parties. Since 2018 only financing from private donors is allowed. Due also to the recent changes in the law, the regulatory framework on political financing and financing during electoral campaigning is quite fragmented. There are several laws regulating electoral campaigns, including aspects concerning the declaration on the donations received and spending, which it may overlap in some parts with the very recent regulation on the transparency of parties, political movements and third parties which was approved in 2019 (2). Thanks to this recent improvement, quite tight transparency obligations on political financing are in place.
Sources

A myriad of laws and reticulations provide details on campaign financing, even though candidates are not required to made these financial information publicly available.",2.0,1.0,1.0,35.275,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Birzeit University,Western Asia,Middle East and North Africa,Amman,Amman,31.9497,35.9328,JO,primary,Integridad Política

Kazakhstan,KAZ,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"According to the national legislation on political parties (1) and elections (2), information on campaign and party finance should be published in mass media. To finance their campaigns, parties can use their own funds or accept donations from citizens and organizations. Foreign and anonymous donations as well as contributions from state sources are prohibited. Within five days after the announcement of election results, each contesting party is obliged to submit a campaign finance report to the Central election commission, who should then publish it on its website.

Korea, South,KOR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Korean government enacted the Political Funds Act on February 19, 1965 to contribute to the sound development of democratic politics by guaranteeing the fair provision of political funds, ensuring the transparency of political funds through the disclosure of the details of their revenues and expenditures and preventing irregularities involving political funds(1). The government also enacted the Public Official Election Act on March 16, 1994 to contribute to contribute to the development of democratic politics by ensuring that elections prescribed by the Constitution of the Republic of Korea and the Local Autonomy Act are held fairly in accordance with the free will of the people and democratic procedures and by preventing any malpractice related to such elections(2). Under these two laws, data on campaign and party finance are regularly collected and published. However, the related data sharing period is limited to 3 months(Article 42 of the Political Funds Act)(1).
Sources

Latvia,LVA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Political party financing in Latvia is regulated by the Law on Financing of Political Organisations (Parties) (1995, amended 2020) [1] as well as Regulation No. 417 and No.591 of the Cabinet of Ministers, which lay down specific provisions concerning the collection and publication of data on parties' finances [2][3]. The Pre-Election Campaign Law (2012, amended 2021) lays down additional provision concerning campaign activities of parties, candidates and third parties [4]. The framework covers all political parties active in the national territory and running for national, local and European elections. The Law on Financing of Political Parties requires political parties to prepare and submit annual reports with information on their assets, liabilities, income and spending as well as declarations of income and expenses of electoral campaigns. The framework also mandates political parties to record and report information on financial contributions, in-kind and non-financial support, and disclose the identity of the donors. Corporate donations are banned. The Law on Pre-Election Campaigns provides clear definitions of campaigning activities, candidates and third parties. Pre-election incomes and expenses of candidates are considered as expenses of the party and accounted in the relevant election declarations. The Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau (CPCB) is the public body in charge of the collection and publication of the data. The framework requires a verification process from the CPCB, which has to carry out audits on annual declarations within 4 months after submission and inspect declaration of electoral incomes and expenditures within one month after the election has taken place. In addition, the CPCB must examine the conformity of donations, gifts and membership fees within 45 days after they have been reported and carry out additional examinations in cases of irregularities. The framework mandates the CPCB to publish on its website annual reports and election statements no later than 10 days after their submission, and information on donations, gifts and membership fees no later than 7 days after they have been reported. Regulations No. 417 and No. 591 lay down provisions for the specific data points to be reported by political parties when submitting information on their finances. For membership fees, gifts and donations these include name of the donors and political parties, type and value of donations and date. As such, the framework supports the collection of structured data.
Sources
(1) Law on the Financing of Political Organisations (Parties) - https://likumi.lv/ta/en/en/id/36189-law-on-financing-of-political-organisations-parties

(2) Regulation No. 417 of the Cabinet of Ministers -https://likumi.lv/ta/en/en/id/309345-regulations-regarding-the-submission-and-publishing-of-the-information-of-political-organisations-parties-regarding-joining-fees-membership-fees-gifts-donations-declarations-of-income-and-expenses-of-elections-and-annual-reports
(3) Regulation No. 591 of the Cabinet of Ministers - https://likumi.lv/ta/id/91251-noteikumi-par-politisko-organizaciju-partiju-un-to-apvienibu-gada-parskatiem

(4) Law on Financing of Pre-Election Campaigns - https://likumi.lv/ta/en/en/id/253543-pre-election-campaign-law",2.0,1.0,1.0,87.875,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Northern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Riga,Riga,56.9489,24.1064,LV,primary,Integridad Política

Liberia,LBR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The laws related to the collection and publication of campaign finances are clear, but for many years now, such information has not been made publicly available. Candidate asset declarations have partially been disclosed as a result of a recent Freedom of Information request by a journalist.

It has been difficult for the asset declaration provisions of the various laws to work since there is no compulsion to publish especially under the Code of Conduct Act which requires the release of declarations only through a court order. Court processes especially for civil cases take an extremely long time in Liberia.

https://zammagazine.com/investigations/1418-the-happy-few-s-happy-places-how-liberian-politicians-and-officials-escape-accounting-for-their-wealth",2.0,1.0,1.0,76.80749999999999,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Local Development Research Institute (LDRI),Western Africa,Africa,Monrovia,Monrovia,6.3133,-10.8014,LR,primary,Integridad Política

Lithuania,LTU,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Law on Political campaign finance and finance control obliges to make all financial contracts, financial and audit reports available for the public (1). Article 10 obliges financial managers of political campaigns to inform Central Electoral Commission about individual donors - natural persons - and insert their names and surnames into the online donors' list (2).

Political campaigns and advertising are described in the Law on Political campaign finance and finance control, however, grey zones still exist. This leads to investigations, trying to unveil if certain publicity events or public appearances were in line with legal regulations (3) (4).
SOURCES:

(1): The Law on Political campaign finance and finance control, No. IX-2428, 2004, https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/TAR.CF812DA6E814/asr (2): Voter's Page, official website of the Central Electoral Commission, https://www.rinkejopuslapis.lt/ataskaitu-formavimas (3): CEC will discuss about possible political advertising at Naisiu summer, news portal lrt.lt, https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/219586/vrk-spres-ar-naisiu-vasaroje-buvo-politines-reklamos (4): Political Advertising on Social Platforms, Transparency International Lithuania, 2020, https://www.transparency.lt/sutarkime-ka-socialiniuose-tinkluose-laikome-politine-reklama/",2.0,1.0,1.0,43.53,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Northern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",Vilnius,Vilnius,54.6872,25.28,LT,primary,Integridad Política

Malawi,MWI,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In Malawi Political financing is totally unregulated. the Political Parties Act of 2018, Presidential and Parliamentary Elections Act and the Constitution of Malawi provides for the provision of both State Political Public financing (which includes funding by the state to all political parties that have attained a prescribed threshold) this is unsustainable as the number of 10% in an election does not relate to the number of seats in parliament,  and Private political Financing ( which includes Private donations, party business, membership fees and other private entities). The Challenge in Malawi is that there is no limit in terms of campaign spending, political parties can spend as they wish. During the 2019 Presidential and Parliamentary Elections evidence was all over as it was difficult to differentiate between a State Function and a Political Campaign Rally. A critical element of the campaign was the incumbent political party widespread and open distribution of cash and items. The presidential and Parliamentary Elections Act on the other hand under section 56 on campaign financing it is also silent in terms of open and transparent financing. As such the sour or manner in which political finances are sources remains a myth. The Polititical Parties Act of 2018 on the other hand accepts the various donations from private entities, thus by considering that:

Donations with a monetary value of at least K1000 000 (US$1 400, 19 February 2019) from an individual donor and at least K2000 000 (US$2 800, 19 February 2019) from an organization must be declared to the Registrar within thirty days of receipt (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (2)(a)).

Furthermore, aggregate donations donated within a month with a monetary value of at least K1000 000 from an individual and at least K2000 000 from an organisation need to be declared (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (2)(b)).

Additionally, persons and organisations who have donated to political parties have to declare to the registrar in cases where the donations exceed K1000 000 for individuals and K2000 000 for organisations (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (4)).

Only the President, Secretary-General or Treasurer-General may formally declare to party funding to the Registrar. Failure by donors or political parties to declare their assets will lead to the those being liable for a fine equal ""to the amount of the funds or the value of the assets not declared or in relation to which false information was given, and to imprisonment for two years"" (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (6)(a) and (b).

Malta,MLT,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Prior to the enactment of the Financing of Political Parties Act (FPPA) political parties were not subject to accounting and disclosure rules (1). The bill was approved in July 2015 and is still in place clearly defining political parties and donations pertaining to them (1). The FPPA tasks the Maltese Electoral Commission with going through the accounts of the various political parties (2). The same act requires parties to keep standard accounting records including records of assets and liabilities (3). While on paper the framework may appear robust, it faces frequent criticism due to lack of enforcement and transparency (4).

column1: Mexico,MEX,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Both the General Law of Political Parties (1) and the GENERAL LAW OF INSTITUTIONS AND ELECTORAL PROCEDURES (2) give the National Electoral Institute full authority to provide guidance in this regard for proper fiscalization and transparency purposes. It is also duly to note that specific data points to be collected are also mandated by the General Law of Transparency and Access to Public Government Information (3), as political parties are part of the obligated subjects under its Article 23. Nonetheless, the relevant electoral framework does not specify the information requirements and the formats.

It is duly to mention that there is a specific website for this regard from the National Electoral Institute (4) that provides useful information. Nonetheless, it only includes public financing, not information on private financing of political activities. It is also worth mentioning that the same institution publishes an open data website that includes information about fiscalization. (5).

Some information about in kind and private financial support can be found in broad numbers in the National Transparency Portal of the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data as required by specific publication formats(6).

(22) pt. 2, mentions that the Central Electoral Commission, as an independent supervisory and control body regarding the financing of political parties and electoral campaigns, ensures collection and publication of reports regarding campaign and party finance. Art. (43) pt. 4 states that the reports shall be placed on the website of the Central Electoral Commission within 48 hours of their receipt, in compliance with the legislation on the protection of personal data. (1)
The Decision No. 2704 from 17-09-2019
for the approval of the Regulation
on the financing of electoral campaigns
of electoral contestants has separate provisions on the reports related to electoral campaigns. They also have to be published within 48 hours after their receipt. (2)
Data is being published on the Central Electoral Commission, although there is no specific mention in the law about the data formats of the reports on party finances.

Mongolia,MNG,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Law on Political Parties and the three laws on Elections are the main regulatory frameworks in Mongolia. All laws require all parties to collect and publish their data on the campaign and party finance. In accordance with laws, political parties are obliged to make their report public but not its data on the website of the General Election Commission of Mongolia(1) Moreover, as stated in Article 20 of the Law on Political Parties, the National Audit Office shall investigate and audit the finance of the party annually(2). Accordingly, the National Audit Office is publishing its audit reports on its web. Although provisions for timing and structure are well-regulated, provisions for openness are not clear. As result, all documents and data are not machine-readable (PDFs and scanned). Because there is no open and available data, users or citizens are not able to explore and analyze it further.
Sources:
(1) General Election Commission of Mongolia, https://www.gec.gov.mn/
(2). Law on Political Parties

Netherlands,NLD,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Act 'financiering politieke partijen' requires political parties to be transparent about their party finance, including the publication gifts, subsidies and liabilities. Each year and with each election, the parties must submit their financial documents to the Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations (1). Donors need to be made public, financial contributions need to be explained, information regarding assets and liabilities needs to be disclosed, just as for income, spending, in-kind and non-financial contributions.

Regarding verification, each political party is obligated to instruct an accountant to examine their financial reports. Each party that participates in the elections has to provide the Minister of Internal Affairs an overview per calendar year with donations above €4500,- and debts more than €25.000,-. For candidates that are on the list of candidates for the elections the same rules apply: donations, gifts, etc. above €4500,- need to be reported per calendar year.  The Commission 'toezicht financiën politieke partijen' made up by three members provides advice regarding the supervision of this Act. For example, analysing the provision of all the required data by each political party, the designation of a legal entity as an ancillary institution, the possible omission of the data of natural persons for security reasons and the imposition of an administrative fine.

New Caledonia,NCL,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"A French colony since 1853, New Caledonia became a French Overseas Territory (TOM) from 1946. New Caledonia is entering the final phase of the self-determination process under the Noumea Accord(May 5, 1998) on the accession of New Caledonia to full sovereignty. This will be decided on December 12, 2021 following a 3rd self-determination referendum (1).

New Caledonia is an overseas collectivity with a special status. Its unique status results from the Nouméa Accord (3), approved during the electoral consultation of November 8, 1998. Organic law n ° 99-209 of March 19, 1999 sets the framework in which the development of the institution of New Caledonia will take place for twenty years. (2)

The Pacific Community (SPC) is an international government organisation that is owned and governed by its member states. New Caledonia is one of three Pacific island French associated territories which make up the 22 Pacific island countries and territories that govern the organisation. As an apolitical organisation, the SPC must remain neutral in matters relating to political governance within our member states. Given the politically sensitive time that New Caledonia is going through leading up to the referendum in December, SPC, as the commissioning organisation for the GDB survey in New Caledonia, has decided to refrain from responding to the questions under the Political Integrity module.

New Zealand,NZL,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"NZ's Electoral Act 1993, Part 6A has mandatory requirements for election expenses and donations(1). The Department of Internal Affairs issues AML-CFT guidance on election financing(2). The Electoral Commission issues guidance(3) and rules on election expenses and donations(4) and reports on party expenditure(5-6). The NZ Serious Fraud Office investigates political party donations that appear to not comply with the legislation and guidelines(7). The regulated election expenses  incurred  for  each  campaign  represent but a fraction of the total that will actually be spent on seeking election. The  full  extent  of  such  expenditure  is  shrouded in mystery as candidates, parties and  promoters  are  required  to  publicly  report  only  on  their  election  expenses  following  each  contest,  not  their  full  campaign accounts(8). There is extensive political and media discussion on this topic(9-12).

However, while it was one of the assumed objectives, the modifications did little to increase transparency in political financing according to Marta Ferrara, executive director of Semillas and expert in political financing (3). Ferrara also mentions a key loophole, which is that political parties are not subject of Law 5282/2014 on the Access to Public Information. In fact, the Electoral Justice Tribunal (Tribunal Superior de Justicia Electoral), the agency in charge to monitor and publish information on political financing received by political movements, alliances, and parties has not published anything on its webpage, contrary to what the law mandates (4).

Romania,ROU,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Although constant efforts have been made to implement all international recommendations, and significant progress has been made in the area of election financing and control, there are still areas considered vulnerable and recommendations considered partially implemented or even not implemented, according to the latest adopted GRECO compliance report on Romania.(1) The Permanent Electoral Authority is the institution that keeps track of reports submitted by political parties regarding funding and spending of money. The institution manages the finantarepartide.ro website, where the parties' financial reports, the Authority's reports on irregularities and sanctions applied on this subject, etc. are constantly uploaded. However, the initiative of the civil society (NGO Expert Forum) - banipartide.ro reveals that the mission of the Authority is a difficult one and difficult to accomplish in optimal terms. One of the problems highlighted by this civil society initiative is that ""the different structure of the reports makes it difficult for an observer to follow both the campaign and the current funding, as the information is only marked differently in some reports"". (2)

Saint Lucia,LCA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In Saint Lucia, there are no laws, policies or regulations requiring the collection or publication of data on campaign and party finance. The Electoral process in Saint Lucia is governed by the Electoral Act along with the relevant official Regulation and Rules to give full effect of the Act.(1) These documents do not speak to campaign financing. There was also an amendment to the Election Act in 2016, which also does not mention campaign financing(2).

According to the publication ""From Grassroots to the Airwaves: Paying for Political Parties and Campaigns in the Caribbean""(3) extensive research on the subject and revealed that although both of the political parties are okay with the idea of campaign financing, it is just not high on the party agendas and has not received much media attention. Indeed, in Saint Lucia it has been almost absent from the media recently, save for the 2017 declaration by the then Prime Minister that there is a need for laws on campaign financing (4).
Sources:
1) Consolidated Electoral Act and Related Regulations, 2008 Attached.
2)Election Amendment, 2016. Attached.
3)https://www.oas.org/sap/docs/publications/grassroots.pdf

Saudi Arabia,SAU,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"There is no political parties or national elections available in Saudi Arabia (1). Saudi Law of Municipal Councils first issued in 2014, in the article 51 the law forbid candidates from receiving any funding from third parties (2). The punishment could be an imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year or a fine not exceeding fifty thousand riyals, or with both penalties.

In the same article, it's mentioned that it's forbidden if the candidate does not disclose the sources of funding for his electoral campaign, and the ways in which it was spent. However there is no mention of funding details in the Executive Regulations for Municipal Councils System.

Sierra Leone,SLE,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Part iv of the Political Parties Act of 2002 provides for the regulation of the conduct of political parties and includes several provisions for collecting data on income, assets, expenditures, and liabilities.

The Act is limited however in stipulating that the said information be published as open. Members of the public can however political party data held at the Political Parties Registration Commission, the institution set up to regulate political parties after paying a fee. Additionally, the law requires the Commission to publish in the National Gazette such income, assets, and expenditure of parties within 30 days of receipt.

Spain,ESP,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"This is an important topic in Spain. The last head of government in Spain was removed from office by Congress for the first time since a democratic regime was restored in the country, falling victim to corruption cases related to the political party. While Law 19/2013 (1), does require economic, budgetary and statistical information to be made public, there is nothing that clearly indicates the obligation to publish information on campaign and party finance, although the collection of this information is required in law 8/2007 on the financing of political parties, article 14, (2) where it indicates that political parties must publish their accounts and balance sheets on their respective websites within a period of one month from the submission of this data to the accounting body.

The general electoral regime law (3) aims to achieve a stable framework for political decisions that reflect the right to vote are carried out in full freedom. Article 81 of the Constitution (4) establishes the need for the General Courts to approve, on an organic basis, a Law that regulates the general electoral regime.

It should be noted that although law 8/2007, of July 4, on financing of political parties, article 14, 8 (2) requires doners' identities to be made public, it only governs those donations superior to 25,000 euros. This same law stipulates that ""all political parties must submit consolidated annual accounts, detailing and documenting their income and expenses"", therefore the information detailed in articles 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 14, and 17 about income and spending should be included.
While information about in-kind and non-financial support is mentioned in article 2 of the aforementioned law, it is not clearly stated if this information should be collected.

The only body that is to process data referred to in this framework is the Court of Auditors and for a strictly auditing purpose, article 19 establishes that the political parties shall be obliged to submit any documents, background information, data and justifications required by the Court of Auditors for the fulfillment of its auditing function, in relation to the verification process it is not clearly detailed, however it is noted in article 19 that the Court of Accounts, if required, will have to comply with the objective of verifying the information - ""(…) if required by the Court of Auditors, to provide it with detailed information and justification on their transactions with them, in accordance with generally accepted external auditing standards, and for the sole purpose of verifying compliance with the limits, requirements and obligations established by this Law"".
1.Law 19/2013, of December 9, on transparency, access to public information and good governance

3.Law 8/2007, of July 4, on financing of political parties,
https://www.boe.es/buscar/pdf/2007/BOE-A-2007-13022-consolidado.pdf

Tajikistan,TJK,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Constitutional Law of the Republic of Tajikistan ""On Elections to the Majlisi Oli"" (1) is the primary framework for governing the electoral activities of the political parties and individuals in Tajikistan.

This information is provided to the commission upon request.
The Law has no mention of the publication of the gathered data as open data, nor of any responsibility to inform the public regarding the financial matters of the campaigns in other ways.

Turkmenistan,TKM,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Law on Political Parties and the Electoral Code of Turkmenistan regulate and guide campaign and party finance. Turkmenistan's legal framework provides for private and public sources of financing for political parties. The framework prohibits donations from state authorities, charities, religious organizations, anonymous and foreign donations. The Law obliges political parties to prepare final financial reports on their incomes and expenditures and the owned property and liabilities, which must be presented to ""designated state bodies"" only (1). The framework, however, does not require making this information available as structured open data. According to the latest available OSCE/ODIHR Election Assessment Report (March 2018), ""regulations on campaign finance are scarce and do not correspond to the reality of how the electoral campaigns are organized"" (2). The existing regulation does not foresee limitations to campaign donations and expenditures, nor any reporting, disclosure, monitoring, or oversight mechanisms. According to the Electoral Code, campaigns and associated costs are directly managed and financed by the Central Electoral Committee, which organizes a uniform electoral campaign for all candidates. The Control and Audit group within the Central Electoral Committee is tasked with controlling the compliance with the established order of financing of election campaigns and imposing the liability on candidates in the event of violations.
Sources
(1)The Law on Political Parties (in Russian), https://minjust.gov.tm/mcenter-single-ru/216

(2)TURKMENISTAN PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS 25 MARCH 2018 ODIHR Election Assessment Mission Final Report, https://www.osce.org/files/f/documents/2/8/382915_0.pdf",2.0,1.0,1.0,22.92,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,IDFI Georgia,Central Asia,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Ashgabat,Ashgabat,37.9375,58.38,TM,primary,Integridad Política

Uganda,UGA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Electoral Commission and the Parliament of Uganda are key in developing the different legal frameworks -

Political Parties and Organisations Act 2005 (1); the Political Parties and Organisations (Amendment) Act 2010 (2); the Presidential Elections Act 2005 (3); and the Presidential Elections (Amendment) Bill, 2019 (4) have aspects on campaigns, political parties and financing of political parties or campaigns in Uganda. However, these legal frameworks do not mention support collection of structured data.

Ukraine,UKR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Campaing and party finance information is very complex. The Election Codex (1) and the Political Party law (2) require the collection and publication of this information. For example, in the Election Codex, depending on the type of elections requires to publish financial reports about the election funds, the National Agency on Corruption Prevention should publish all reports about parties. The problem is that the election funds report of the MP candidates from single member districts and candidates on local election are available only on the level of local election comissions and sometimes it is hard to get it as they are not always published or publicly available.
There are different orders that requlate the structure of financial reports, different procedures and responsibilities for not doing that correctly or in time (3).
Meanwhile published data are with very law quality and one should refine it and work a lot on making this data machine-readable, part of data is missing, part is not provided due to COVID (4).
Sources (Accessed 30 July - 6 August 2021):
(1) The Election Codex: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/396-20/print
(2) The Political Party law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2365-14/print
(3) Violations Codex: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/80731-10

(4) Interview with Igor Feshchenko, Chesno, 30 July 2021",2.0,1.0,1.0,91.7,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,IDFI Georgia,Eastern Europe,Eastern Europe and Central Asia,Kyiv,Kyiv,50.45,30.5233,UA,primary,Integridad Política

United Arab Emirates,ARE,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"UAE have elections only related to Federal National Council (FNC). According to UAE constitution article 69 (1) an Emirate is free to determine the method of selection of its representatives in the FNC. Only after 2006, UAE started organizing elections to the FNC since 2006 by virtue of the Resolution No. 3 of 2006, issued by H. H. Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, President of the UAE (2).

There is no relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance. According to the election committee, candidate should provide its Emirate with a report of campaign finance, however there is no legal obligation or follow up process (3).

United Kingdom,GBR,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"Campaign and political finance is regulated through The Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000 (PPERA)[1] (amended 2015). The Transparency of Lobbying, Non-Party Campaigning and Trade Union Administration Act 2014 additionally regulates third-party campaign expenditure, with mandatory recording[2], plus reporting if campaigners spend over £10,000.

The PPERA mandates the collection of specific information on donations and transactions - including non-financial and in-kind - and requires parties to disclose their accounts and all financial information to the Electoral Commission. The Commission publishes all this data,[3] but there is no clear legal requirement for how to do this. The licensing of the data is unclear.

Transparency International has raised concerns about some of the limitations of the UK regime, including the lack of limits on donations, only on spending, and the possibility that funding can still be hidden through company donations. Foreign actors can influence policy through travel and employment of politicians.[4]

Campaign finance became a huge political scandal after the Brexit referendum, when Leave campaign groups were accused of various irregularities. The Electoral Commission has investigated and fined parties and other actors.[5]
Partly as a response, the Elections Bill 2021[6] was presented to the House of Commons on 5 July 2021 and it would change some of the rules around campaign financing.
[1] Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/41/contents
[2] Transparency of Lobbying, Non-Party Campaigning and Trade Union Administration Act 2014. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2014/4/contents/enacted
[3] The Electoral Commission search, 2021. http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk
[4] HAPPY ANNIVERSARY PPERA! 2020. https://www.transparency.org.uk/uk-political-parties-elections-referendums-act-2000-PPERA
[5] Electoral Commission Investigations, 2021. https://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/who-we-are-and-what-we-do/our-enforcement-work/investigations

[6] Elections Bill, 2021. https://bills.parliament.uk/bills/3020",2.0,1.0,1.0,77.13749999999999,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Northern Europe,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",London,London,51.5072,-0.1275,GB,primary,Integridad Política

United States,USA,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In the United States, there are federal campaign finance regulations and various local campaign finance regulations. The first federal campaign finance law, the Tillman Act, was enacted in 1907. In the years following the enactment of that law, campaign finance has remained a source of contention in American politics. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002, and a series of federal court cases, including Buckley v. Valeo and Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, together form the foundation of federal campaign finance law. Campaign finance laws require disclosure of income and spending of candidates and their committee affiliates and disclosure of individual donor information. (1)

Campaign finance e-filing is required by law (§ 104.18 Electronic filing of reports (52 U.S.C. 30102(d) and 30104(a)(11))) for committees if they receive contributions or make expenditures in excess of $50,000 in the current calendar year, or have reason to expect to do so and encourages voluntary electronic filers. (2) When this data is electronically filed it is run through a validator to ensure standard open data. (3) The FEC website reiterates the legal definitions of clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties. (4) The FEC Website provides an API, searchable database, and bulk open data. (5)
Sources:
1. Ballotpedia - US Campaign Finance Laws, https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_campaign_finance_laws_and_regulations
2. FEC - Regulations, https://www.fec.gov/regulations/104-18/2021-annual-104#104-18
3. FEC - e-filing instructions, https://www.fec.gov/help-candidates-and-committees/filing-reports/electronic-filing/
4. FEC website, https://fec.gov

5. FEC data webpage, https://fec.gov/data",2.0,1.0,1.0,95.0,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,Access Info Europe,Northern America,"European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand",New York,New York,40.6943,-73.9249,US,admin,Integridad Política

Uruguay,URY,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"The Law 18.485 regulates the functioning of the political parties in Uruguay, it was approved in 2009 (1,2). It states conditions for public and private funding, including a threshold for for anonymous donations, and how parties must present their accountability to the electoral authority.
