Uzbekistan,UZB,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In Uzbekistan, there are 5 formal parties and 4 Public associations[1]:
Formal parties
1.People's Democratic Party of Uzbekistan
2.UZLiDeP / Liberal Democratic Party of Uzbekistan
3.UzDP / Democratic Party of National Revival of Uzbekistan
4.SDP Adolat / Social Democratic Party of Uzbekistan Adolat
5.Ecoparty / Ecological Party of Uzbekistan
Public associations
1.Youth Union of Uzbekistan
2.Uzbekistan Youth Future Foundation
3.Uzbek Center for Spirituality and Enlightenment
4.National Movement for the Rise of Uzbekistan
Political parties have the right to nominate a candidate for the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, a candidate for the Legislative Chamber, and a candidate for local councils[2].

Political parties and their organizations are prohibited from having bank accounts with more than one bank, as well as accounts in foreign banks(Article 6, Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Financing of Political Parties)[3].
Political parties have to report on their election campaign finances.

A political party must annually submit financial reports on financial and other funds received and spent during the reporting period to the financial authorities, state tax service, the Accounts Chamber and the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Uzbekistan within the timeframe and in the manner prescribed by law.

A political party shall submit to the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Uzbekistan an interim report on the day of elections on the state funds allocated to it to finance its participation in the elections, and after the announcement of the election results "";

The financial report of a political party must contain information on the sources and amounts of funds received during the reporting period, the expenditure of these funds, the value of the property of the political party, as well as the state registration of the party.

If charitable assistance is received from legal entities and citizens of the Republic of Uzbekistan in other forms, the political party shall evaluate it in monetary terms in accordance with the legislation of the Republic of Uzbekistan and include relevant information, including information on the charitable donor in the financial party's financial statements.
The financial report of a political party contains the receipt and expenditure of public funds in a separate section.
In this case, the funds spent by a political party to participate in the election shall be taken into account separately.

The form of the report on financing the participation of a political party in the elections and the deadline for its submission shall be determined by the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Uzbekistan.
The reports of the political party will be published on its official website and in print(Article 16, Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Financing of Political Parties)[3].

Leaders of political parties reported on the financing of the party's activities in 2020 and its sources. The UzLiDeP party received 35.3 billion soums, which is the largest amount transferred to the parties. The main sources of funding for the National Revival and UzLiDeP parties were the state budget. 48% of the PDP's expenses are covered by its own funds[4].

According to the interim report[5] of OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights in 2019, The legislation on the registration of political parties – which ODIHR had assessed as burdensome and open to arbitrary application – remains largely unchanged. The only registered parties are those represented in parliament. With the exception of the Ecological Party of Uzbekistan (EPU), no new party has been registered since 2003 (with the exception of the DPU – Milliy Tiklanish, which was established through a merger of Milliy Tiklanish and the National Democratic Party Fidokorlar, in 2008.) According to the Ministry of Justice, no applications have been received either.

Vietnam,VNM,Governance,POLITICAL INTEGRITY,G.PI.POLFIN,Governance (PI): Political finance,Primary,G.PI.POLFIN,"To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance?",1,response,"In Vietnam, election of deputies to the National Assembly and People's Councils includes political campaigns. There are no party political campaigns. Article 6 of the Law on election of deputies to the National Assembly and People's Councils states that ""Election funding for election of deputies to the National Assembly and People's Councils shall be ensured by government budget."" Technically, by the Law on State Budget, data on election expenditure is supposed to be published. But there is no data on this.

There are regulations requiring collection and publication of party finance. Article 15, Law on State budget 2015, technically requires collection and publication of party finance (For more information, please see Public Finance section).

According to Art.46 of the Communist Party Vietnam's Charter and No.33 of Regulation No 29/QĐ-TW on implementation The Party Charter, political finance information of the Party are published within each level of the Party committee (from central to local levels) and in each member organization in accordance with the state budget year. Annually, the Party finance agencies at all levels are responsible for reporting the previous year's budget finalization and the next year's estimate to their respective level committees. Therefore, only Party members can access to political finance information.

The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions, income and spending",2.0,1.0,1.0,15.77,G.PI.POLFIN,0.0,51241.0,0.065,0.0195,0.075,East-West Management Institute Inc.
